I apologize for this long thread and evident portions of humblebrag. My intention isn't to impress.

Look beyond the numbers. They are just that. 
Numbers.

This new year, I would love for all of you to find that one thing you can do every day/week/month/year that works for you and doesn't bore you, while looks like work for everyone else.

Because in that one repeatable thing, you would have found yourself!

3. Most importantly, remind you that it is the boring that makes shit happen.

When people ask me, 'What's next?"
I do not have an answer.
There is no next.
There is just repeat.
Repeat what works.
And give it time.

It is the biggest thing I have learnt in life. https://t.co/HCNbY0vv6w

2. Acknowledge my awesome team @waricrew
 who have ensured that we stayed true to our belief.

"Keep creating content that helps people make aware choices in life."

We are in it for the long-term and we are not chasing any goals.
Just a process!

The reason I share this, is for 3 reasons

1. Thank those who make this happen
@Razorpay @asana @zoom @ConvertKit @LearnWorlds @zapier @Adobe @Google @FreshworksInc @Frame_io @Calendly @canva @envato, ScaleX
It's wild how much is available at our disposal today to run a business

All of this while

1. Running a full-remote team spread across 6 cities (and meeting every quarter for an offsite)

2. Running a no-code operation (my software bill is the biggest spend after marketing)

3. Spending less than 20hrs/week working

My high points:

1. Distributing 60L towards the education of 129 kids

2. Distributing 75L within the team as part of the profit pool (an avg intern earned ~10L this year at @wariCrew)

3. People sharing that DO EPIC SHIT was the first ever non-academic book they read!

Across the 2 business units, revenue rose from 11.9Cr ($1.5M) in 2021 to 27Cr ($3.4M) in 2022.

But my high point wasn't this...

And that's just the start. 
Think offline courses, think fellowship programs, think international markets and you potentially have a $100M biz in the making over the next decade, should I want to build it so.

This business, while lower margin (ad spend is 50% of biz), has the potential to be 100X of what it is today.

Every new course we launch, can add $0.3M-$1M per year to revenue. 
Our flagship time management course does $1M/yr
I have 10 such courses in the pipeline!

In 2021, we sold courses worth 7.68Cr ($1M)
In 2022, that rose to 12.97Cr ($1.6M).

Last year 117,000+ students brought our courses. 
We ended 2022 at 279,000+ students!

83% completion rate
~5% refund rate

My courses business (called WebVeda) intends to create courses that help young Indians get life-ready.

These courses are:
1. Fully on-demand
2. Low priced (avg price point Rs. 700)
3. 100% refundable 

I am not building an elite institution.
I am building a mass institution.

People see my content, it hopefully helps them, adds some value to their lives because of which, over time they trust me.

And if they trust me, they are likelier to buy into my main objective - teach them to be life-ready - through my 2nd business unit: courses

In all, the Content & Community business unit earned 14.3Cr ($1.8M) 

This is an immensely profitable business, but as mentioned not a scalable business. Will this ever be a 160Cr ($20M) revenue biz? I doubt it. 

But what biz does is create visibility driven by trust.

4. Brand Collabs
I work with brands that I personally use or whose founders I have known from the past, endorsing them through my content.

In 2021, we earned 5.48Cr ($685K) in brand collabs.
In 2022, this role to 10.58Cr ($1.3M)

3. Corporate Talks/Appearances
Companies seek my time for keynote employee sessions. 
Or seek my time for flagship corporate events/initiatives.
For such gigs, I charge for my time.

In 2021, we earned 54L ($67K) through this.
In 2022, this rose to 2.03Cr ($253K)

2. Book Royalty
My first book DO EPIC SHIT launched in Dec 2021, so there was no royalty income in 2021.
In 2022, we earned a mind-boggling 1.04Cr ($130K) in book royalty. 
When I heard this number, I was stunned.

Thank you @Chikisarkar @juggernautbooks for making it happen :)

..this amount was 27L ($33K)
In 2022, we earned 60L ($75K) in affiliate income.
100% of this income is used to sponsor the education of kids who cannot afford it.
Last year 53 students were helped. 
This year 129 kids have been helped. 

Thank YOU ALL for making it happen :)

This scale generated revenue across 4 categories

0. YT Ad Revenue
This is 0 for the brand, because I do not run ads on my videos. 

1. Affiliate Income
This is revenue we earn through sharing links of brands. When you buy, we get a share of the revenue the brand makes.
In 2021..

Let's start with the basics

I run a company called WebVeda, the goal of which is to make young Indians life-ready. 

The company has 2 business units
1. Content & Community (CnC)
2. Courses

Last calendar year (Jan-Dec 2021), our business did 12.68Cr ($1.6M) of Revenue with 3.9Cr ($480K) of profits.

There were 4 main sources of income
1. Courses 
2. Corporate Talks
3. Brand Collabs
4. Affiliate Income

I expected this year to be much slower. But...

We made 27Cr ($3.5M) revenue this year.
100% bootstrapped; up 150% from last year; immensely profitable; team of 9 people. 
All of this in less than 3 years of existence.

As we get ready to say goodbye to 2022 and say hello to a brand new year, here is a small gift you can give yourself.

‚ÄúI trust you!‚Äù
The three magical words.
Spread this magic in 2023, for others.

For your own self!
Which of these hit you the hardest?

22. If you are loved only when you are around, then it‚Äôs not love.

It‚Äôs convenience.

Bonus:
The only thing that matters in the world is your opinion about your own self.

19. If your parents are not rich, but you got a good education, be grateful for their sacrifices.

20. A truly happy person will never troll anyone.

21. The face can be misleading. Fall in love with the mind.

15. True growth lies in doing the boring things over and over again.

16. When in doubt don't ask what should I do. Instead ask what do I WANT to do. Solve for making that happen.

17. If you aren't happy doing it, why are you still in it?

18. Focus on effort, not results.

12. The day you stop asking 'when should I do it', is the day you are ready to do it.

13. We all have two money lives. The second one begins when we realize we have enough money for our life.

14. If you say the truth, you do not have to remember what you said to whom.

8. The hardest thing is to focus. The easiest thing is to complain.

9. You will free yourself the day you forgive your parents and stop blaming them.

10. The more available you are, the less respected you'd be.

11. If you truly know who you are, no one can ever touch you!

5. A beautiful life is to know how to live alone, but never have the need to.

6. Your fear of embarrassing yourself, is your biggest hurdle to growth.

7. No one is coming to save you. Your life is 100% your responsibility.

1. You can change your past by changing the meaning of your memories.

2. The smarter you get, the faster you lose friends.

3. Money doesn't change you. It amplifies who you truly are.

4. ‚Ä¢ You don't suck at managing your time, you just don't know how valuable it is.

Here are 22 of them.

Bonus:
Money cannot buy hard work

You may be the smartest one out there, the one with the highest intent, the most potential - but the ability to roll up your sleeves, to show up everyday, to fall down and get back up - is not available for sale!

A well built physique reflects you worked hard for it, no money can buy it.
You cannot borrow it, inherit it, or steal it.
You cannot hold onto it without constant work.
It shows discipline, it shows self respect, patience, work ethic and passion.
- Arnold Schwarzenegger

11/ Money cannot buy a healthy body

Money can buy you healthy food, supplements, trainers, equipment, and access.
But it can never buy you the body you feel proud of in front of the mirror.

10/ Money cannot buy a great idea

Money can help execute, money can help deliver, money can help plan, money can help organize.
But money cannot help you think.

Great ideas come from creativity, inspiration, and imagination, which cannot be purchased with money.

9/ Money cannot buy a good reputation

Money can surely make you famous, get you attention, get you visibility, and even help form an opinion about you.

But money cannot buy you a good reputation.
What people say once you leave the room, is a function of your conduct. Not money.

8/ Money cannot buy luck

We increase our chances of getting lucky, by taking more shots at the same thing.
Not by buying our way through the process.

If money makes you feel lucky, it is not luck.
It is confidence.

7/ Money cannot buy your child's laugh

Kids don't understand and appreciate money.
When they smile at you, laugh with you, play with you, they do so because it is you.
And in that moment, they complete you.
Irrespective of how much money you have or don't.

6/ Money cannot buy emotional regulation

Money can help you understand your emotions through professionals, manage them through medication, numb them through indulgences, but money cannot help you regulate your emotions.

That's a journey one has to undertake by themselves.

5/ Money cannot buy intimacy

Money can buy you companionship, support, even sex.
But not intimacy.

That is felt. Not bought.

4/ Money cannot buy morality

Money doesn't change who you are.
It reveals who you are.

So if you are immoral, money will amplify that immorality.
You can buy those morals off the shelf!

3/ Money cannot buy peace

Money can buy you happiness, it can buy you comfort, it can buy you freedom.
But peace is not up for a transaction.

That is only to be found within.
Not purchased.

2/ Money cannot buy true relationships

Money can certainly get you attention, popularity and even relationships.
But the truest relationships will form irrespective of your money.
And they most conclusively cannot be made truer, through that money.

@SahilBloom wrote this brilliant thread recently on how and with who we spend our time with. A reminder that even the richest people on Earth perhaps go through the same cycle.

1/ Money cannot buy lost time

Contrary to popular opinion, money can actually buy you time. Through tools, processes and even people.

However time, once lost, cannot be recovered.

Time, once lost, leaves us with either of these two things.
Regret. Or Results.

Money, in the hands of good people, is a good thing!

Work hard for money. Make it happen. Be smart about it.

But know how much you need.
Know how much is 'enough'
And when you get there, enjoy the money.
Make it work for you.
Buy the things that money can buy for you!

As Confucius said "We all have two lives. The second one begins when we realize we just have one."

I paraphrase this about money, "We all have two money lives. The second one begins when we realize we have enough for our life."

You can either go after money all your life, or go beyond money.

Those who go after it, see it as a powerful thing.
Those who go beyond it, see it as a beautiful thing.

The choice remains ours.

Heller responds, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got something he can never have.‚Äù
Kurt said, ‚ÄúWhat on earth could that be, Joe?‚Äù
Joe said, ‚ÄúThe knowledge that I‚Äôve got enough.‚Äù

Money gives you the power to know what is enough.
Without you, you will never know. With it, you might.

11/ Money can buy 'enough'

At a party given by a billionaire, Kurt informs his pal, Joseph (Joe) Heller, that their host, a hedge fund manager, had made more money in a day than Heller had earned from his wildly popular novel Catch-22 over its whole history.

10/ Money can buy the ability to give

To help those who do not sit on the same privileges that you and I sit on.
To realize that not every success is due to hard work and not every failure due to laziness.
To recognize our privilege and use that to create good.

9/ Money can buy help

Someone to drive you around, someone to take care of the chores, someone to train you, someone to coach you.

Money allows you to tap into other people's experience and expertise and gain from them.

8/ Money can buy freedom

To do what you want to do with your time, while your money works for you.
To be able to slow down in life, because you want to.
To be able to live life on your terms.

7/ Money can buy happiness

To give your parents what they always deserved, to gift your siblings what they always craved for, to pamper your partner - so that you find happiness in their happy moments.

6/ Money can buy comfort

A good mattress, good shoes, warm clothes, heating, air-conditioning, gadgets - things that make it joyful to live your days.

5/ Money can buy experiences

Travel, concerts, safaris, cruises, amusement parks, once-in-a-lifetime events - money creates opportunities for you to experience what the world has to offer, at its finest.

4/ Money can buy options

This college or that?
This job which pays less but offer more learning, or the job with more money?
Take a break from work, or continue slogging?

Money allows you to create options for yourself.

3/ Money can buy safety

Just the privilege to have your own transport, to live in a secure safe neighborhood, to be able to afford security, is often something we dismiss, if we have it easy.

2/ Money can buy good quality food

Junk food is cheap for a reason. Because it's bad for you.

We are (unfortunately) living in an era where good quality healthy food is expensive.
Money gives you the luxury to access that.

1/ Money can buy peace of mind

I know what it is to go to bed worried about how you are going to pay the bills, the school fees, the EMIs, the salaries.

And its crazy how it's often not a lot of money, that can actually give you that peaceful night's sleep.

11 things that money CAN buy!

Some references that might help:

Money is a good servant, but a bad master.

- Francis Bacon

11. We all have 2 lives when it comes to money

- Get to the amount you need to live life and do all the things you want to do and need to do.
- Make more money

1 is mandatory.
Will take time.
If you try to find shortcuts, you won't get past it.

2 is optional & a LOT of fun!

10. You (most likely) do not know how much money you are chasing. Hence you will keep chasing forever!

Do you know how much money is that, for you?

9. Money will not change you. It will reveal you.

If you are an inherently kind person, money will make you kinder.
If you are an inherently charitable person, money will make you more charitable.
If you are an inherently proud person, money will make you prouder.

8. Rich does not mean wealthy

You are rich when your active income is a lot.
You are wealthy when your passive income equals or exceeds living expenses.

7. Money's job is to set you free, not make you rich!

Money gives you choices, it gives you options, it gives you freedom.
At the best end of the spectrum, it gives you your time.

That is when money has truly worked for you.

6. No one wants to get rich slowly.

The surest way of getting rich is to be patient with it.
- Build multiple streams of income
- Keep expenses low
- Do not take loans to buy things that make you look rich
- Invest every month, whether up or down
It is boring!

5. Your partner will influence your money, more than your knowledge.

Who you spend your life with, their worldview, their approach towards money, their rick profile - all have a far bigger influence on how you treat your money, than your own knowledge.

4. Spending money for your well being is an investment.

Buying a comfortable chair to WFH, is an investment, not an expense.
Eating healthy, is an investment.
A good pair of shoes, a good mattress, a good pillow - are investments.
Therapy is an investment.

Don't be cheap here!

3. You play safe with your money, if you do not know how to make it again.

Until you do not understand a way of making more money from money, you will always hold on to the money you have.

2. It is (mostly) more profitable to rent than to buy

Buying is mostly an emotional decision, stemming from a worldview that ownership means success.

Buy, when you have excess.
Rent, when you are on a budget.

1. Money DOES BUY happiness.

It is not money that makes you unhappy.
It is chasing money as makes you unhappy.

11 shocking facts about money.

If you liked this thread, you might like my next book ' Get Epic Shit Done' where I answer 36 life questions, in a QnA format between a student & teacher.

Section 4 of the book is on managing yourself, where I go deep into routine and habit building.

https://t.co/zMfZoGdOFS
A pro is the amateur who showed up every day!

A routine beats everything else.

It beats money, it beats talent, and it even beats luck!
A routine gives you all of it.

3. A routine needs a record

We are horrible at remembering things.
A routine needs an artifact that shows the past, present and future of it.
So that you spend your mind executing. Not remembering.

PS: This is my (google) calendar for 18th Nov next year. This routine is fixed! https://t.co/iOyhRsz3eL

2. Routine needn't be repeated every day.

It can be every week, fortnight, month, qtr, year.
The key to a routine is not the frequency of repetition.
It is the act of repetition itself - leading to a habit. https://t.co/Xd2KQIsbIX

3 things that will help you build your routine.

1. Your routine is specific to your current context.

For ex:
- Student's routine: sleep, food, school/college, self study and chill time.
- Working professional's routine: sleep, food, work, personal growth,  friends/family time.

So within a day, I have 3 routines.
1. A set routine comprising tasks.
2. A fluid routine comprising thinking and reflecting.
3. A routine to waste time.

Whether you are a student, a working professional, a homemaker, a freelancer, an entrepreneur - a routine is critical.

I end my day with an early meal, spending time with family, reading again and sleeping early.
That is ALSO a routine.

And then during the day, I have my distraction time scheduled.

Time that I have scheduled to 'waste time' (mostly on social media, mostly IG reels, haha).
That is ALSO a routine.

However when I sit down for my work, I have a very different routine.

That routine is to spend 1-2 hours everyday with NO AGENDA.
I read online, browse twitter, write on paper, reflect, look out the window, take breaks.
And that is ALSO a routine.

I have a morning routine, that I love.
I wake up, meditate, read, get the kids ready for school, play tennis, go to the gym, get ready, have a nice breakfast.
This is the most important part of my day.
That is my routine.

Which means, it can very well be a routine to 'do nothing'.

Let me explain, using my life as an example.

A routine is NOT moving from one task to another.
A routine is doing something repeatedly to the point it becomes natural to your life.
These seemingly poor choices emerge because of a lack of understanding of what comprises a routine.

Choice 2 is to have a routine.
Stick to a calendar. Be organized.
But that leads to a boring life - we look like a robot, moving from one task to another!

It seems that the world offers two really poor choices.

Choice 1 is to not have a routine.
Go with the flow.
But that ends up making us feel guilty of not managing our time effectively, procrastinating and ultimately not accomplishing the things we wanted to.

I was recently asked:
"You seem to be a person of routine. However, does a routine leave space for serendipity, luck or just casual thinking? When you are so set in your calendar, are you not a slave to the calendar itself?"

It's a brilliant question.

3 ways to build a routine for yourself.

Which books would you add to this list?

The key to life is not to read as many books as possible.
It is to re-read the books that served you well. 

These 10 books have helped me from the day I first read them, to every year that I continue to pick them up.
A new book, a new meaning, a new view emerges each time!

10. Atomic Habits by James Clear @JamesClear 

Tells us the power of tiny habits, that slowly and steadily bring about massive changes in one's life.
One of the most liberating books one will read.

https://t.co/rLq0IWdXdm

9. Almanack of Naval Ravikant by Eric Jorgenson @EricJorgenson 

A terrific compilation of @naval's thoughts on building wealth and creating long-term happiness.
A book that will inspire you to create your own path, as against follow someone else's!

https://t.co/TkRhxXGksi

8. Psychology of Money by Morgan Housel @morganhousel 

Tells us that making money isn't as much about knowing how to, as it is about how you behave with money.
Possibly the only money book one needs to read!

https://t.co/Xaz3dl865c

7. Rework by Jason Fried @jasonfried and DHH @dhh 

Tells us how to reimagine work, breaking most notions that have been set by the world, fed by the world. 
Possibly the most unique business book one will read!

https://t.co/JLhVfaCVhT

Every week, I write a thread on life, failure, success, productivity or startups - things that I actively care about.

Follow me on @warikoo to be notified of my threads and tweets.

Candor is a compliment.
It implies equality.
It is how true friends talk.

- Peggy Noonan

I hope this helped you realize where you could be going wrong.

Or, where someone you know could be going wrong and you can now, through Radical Candor, help them see it :)

It‚Äôs my biggest weakness because I still fall in that trap.

Of wanting to help myself (they should feel I am a nice person), than helping them!

I have come to believe that most relationships falter because they never engage in Radical Candor.

Question 3: Will this feedback help them or help me?

Things that I said which, in hindsight helped only me and not them, was not feedback.
It was just my need to express myself.
The chart above helped me a lot.

I am most guilty of ruinous empathy.

Today, I make sure that I want them to win by whatever I say.

For ex:
"You do not even know why I am angry" - is an unfair statement to make.
It makes it sound like you WANT the other person to forget, and use that as an excuse to remind them of their failure.

Question 2: Do I want the other person to truly win, or would I feel happy watching them lose?

I found myself in situations where I wanted the person to lose, so that I could pin point their mistakes, go one up on them and thus establish authority the next time I said something.

In hindsight - none of those remarks ever helped.

It just made them more defensive or exercise authority if they could.
Now, I ask a different question:
‚ÄúWhat is it that they know that I do not?‚Äù
That helps me see their side and approach it from that direction.

Question 1: Am I saying this because I feel anger or frustration?

I was guilty of this during my Groupon days.

Where a lot of what I said was simply anger/frustration because the US team had no idea what Asia needs or wants and they were simply imposing the US understanding.

Because now I had a way of managing my guilt of being harsh towards someone I cared for.

So today, before giving any feedback to any of my known ones, I ask these 3 questions:

Top Right Quadrant:
It is ONLY when you challenge directly AND you care personally about the person you are giving feedback - that it is Radical Candor.

RC leads to instant change and needless to say, profound in nature!

The book hit me hard.

Top Left Quadrant:
If you do care about the person, but do not challenge directly, it is ruinous empathy.

It results in ignorance (people do not even know what to fix, if at all to fix anything) and thus no change.

This is what I was guilty of, for the longest time!

Bottom Left Quadrant:
If you do not care about the person but you do not challenge directly either, instead sugar coat and pretend to be all nice and warm - that is manipulative insincerity.

Most toxic relationships lie here.
This results in mistrust and again, no change!
The end result of such an approach is instant defensiveness. With little change in the person we gave the feedback to.

Bottom Right Quadrant:
If you challenge the person directly, but you do not care for the person - then that is obnoxious aggression!

This is when you are harsh, you are rude, you are not being helpful.

We all know how that feels, because we have felt it.

Basis these 2 determinants, Kim showed the four types of feedback.

Let's try and understand them: https://t.co/eiV37Uszsp

One, do you care personally about the person you are giving feedback to - whether your friend, your relative, your colleague, whosoever!

Second, are you direct with that person or not? Or do you twist and turn or sugar coat your feedback?

Until, I read the book 'Radical Candor'.

In this brilliant book by Kim Scott, Kim explains 4 types of feedback and how only one of them is effective.

To explain that, she uses two determinants.

For the longest time, I struggled with giving direct feedback.

I felt I was being too harsh, I felt they will feel hurt, they might not like me, they will confront me and I will not know how to defend.

A million things used to go on in my head.

How to have difficult conversations.

Every Friday I write a thread sharing my thoughts on failure, life, success, productivity.

Follow me on @warikoo to be notified of these threads when they go live.
Fewer the facts around how to live life, stronger will be the opinions around it.

Listen to the world opinion's as THEIR opinions about what THEY wish THEY did in THEIR life (similar to this thread)

DO NOT assume that it applies to your life too.

So here is something to consider

Instead of an instruction manual, wish for a mirror.

A mirror that can make you an observer of your own life.
So that you can see yourself, hear yourself, feel yourself.
And thus heal yourself, soothe yourself, grow yourself.

Growing up, it often felt like 'shit man, why does life not come with an instruction manual?"

And then it hit me - that instruction manual will be written by the very same people whose opinions I do not agree with, thus hoping for an instruction manual.

Truth I realized:
EVERYTHING happens ALL the time!

Life comprises 4 elements - Family, friends, health and work.
And you do not attend to them one after the other.
You attend to them all at once.

That is life!

Lie 13:
First work hard. Then enjoy your life.

This boils me the most.
Focus on your studies, your job, your stability.
Once you have that, you can enjoy life.

It made me believe that there is a sequential way to life life.
Step 1
Step 2
Step 3
Follow and you get everything!

Truth I realized:
Everyone is struggling!

You are not the only one confused.
You are not the only one unsure.
You are not the only one struggling.

You are not dumb, inadequate, incapable.

Everyone is struggling.
Everyone is figuring it out.

Don't be harsh on yourself.

Lie 12:
Everyone else is sorted. Why are you so confused about life?

Everyone has their shit figured!
They are winning.
They are in complete control.
They have everything.
What do you have?

There was always a 'sharmaji ka beta' lurking, available for a quick comparison.

Truth I realized:
What you think of yourself, matters!

If you truly know yourself, no one can touch you!

You then use the world to improve yourself, not to judge yourself!

Lie 11:
What the world thinks of you, matters!

The world will define your worth.
It will tell you what you can or cannot do.
It will appraise you. Promote you. Fire you. Admit you. Offer you. Reject you.

You have to spend your time, pleasing the world.

Truth I realized:
You live life on your own pace

Don't feel it today?
That's ok.
Don't work.
Don't feel like doing anything?
That's ok.
Don't.

Feel this way, for a sec, min, day, week, month!
Time is NOT running out, unless you do not make that feeling your permanent reality.

Lie 10:
Be productive. ALL the time!

In your 20s, every hour wasted, is an hour that you could have spent in making more money, find new friends, learn new things, find new opportunities, network, watch 60 more ads of warikoo!

Hustle, bro! Hustle!

Truth I realized:
Life's purpose is to help yourself

You spread happiness, only when you are truly happy.
You listen, only when you can listen to your own thoughts.
You give, only when you know how to build within.

Else you will always know you are a fake!

Lie 9:
Life's purpose is to help others

There was something magical being someone who was helping others.
You know, the SRK of their lives.
Making them happy, always giving, rarely taking, listening to them, solving their problems.

'Main hoon naa' had to be a life motto!

Truth I realized:
Being helpful >>> being nice

That might mean, the other person may not appreciate you for your honesty in that moment.

But you center yourself on 'am I being helpful here?"

If yes, you do not care about being liked.
You care about them!

Lie 8:
Be nice to people

Of course, be nice to people.
I realized the world was actually telling me was - be nice to people, even if that means telling a lie.
Tell lies to manipulate people to get to like you.
b/c no one wants to hear the truth.
So why bother?

Truth I realized:
20s is the decade of habits

What we do this decade, sets us up for life.
Because this decade is when we experience work, relationships and money for the first time.
And our early experience with them, decide our eventual experience with them.

Lie 7:
20s is to chill. Don't take life so seriously!

The world had a split personality.
No, seriously!

One day they would ask me to settle down.
The same evening, they would tell me to eat shit and party, because YOLO!

As if we are meant to live two lives this decade!

Truth I realized:
Express yourself in a way that HELPS you

Whenever I listened to my emotions and respected them, I felt stronger.
Even if I had tears in that moment.

I converted my emotions into my strength, not my weakness.
By allowing them entry.

Lie 6:
As a guy, don't cry!

I was told my role is to be strong, to not exhibit weakness, to sit with my legs wide open, to not share my problems and not to seek help either!
To be someone they called alpha.

If I cried watching Titanic, I was to be thrown out of the club.

Truth I realized:
When you find the right person, you find the one to SHARE your happiness with.

If you are not happy within, and you expect the other person to make you happy, game over my friend.
b/c everytime you are sad, you expect them to solve for it! :(

Lie 5:
When you find the right person, you will find happiness.

Being in love was imagined to be a happiness grant.
Once you found the love of your life, you will find in them an eternal source of happiness.

All you will have to do is to say 'I love you' infinitely :))

Truth I realized:
You are not rewarded for being fast.
You are rewarded for being accurate.

Accuracy >> Speed >> Perfection

Lie 4:
Speed = capability

If you are capable, intelligent, you should be able to do your work faster than others.
Recall those kids that finished the 4hr exam in 2hrs - yeah that shit!

So I did the same at work.
Turned in my work faster.
With errors!
b/c speed >> perfection!

The truth I realized:
Don't try to be smart.
Try to be understood.

If people understand you, that is being smart!
If people find you relatable, that is being smart.
If people are not intimated by you, instead find you approachable, that is being smart.

Lie 3:
You have to come across as smart.

That became life's goal.
Read books that made you look smart.
Use words that made you sound smart.
Hang out with people who made you smart.

You were judged if you said or did things that it didn't consider smart!

The truth I realized:
Money doesn't buy you things.
Money buys you time.
Time to do what YOU want to do.

At your own pace.
On your own terms.

Lie 2:
Money buys you success.

I saw everyone run after money.
The best jobs.
The highest increment.

Because they wanted to buy anything they set their mind to, without looking at the price tag.
Because the world called that success.

The truth I realized:
20s is the decade for you to explore.

It is when you can take the max risk, you have the highest energy, you are excited about the future.

This is the decade where you do everything to discover yourself.

Lie 1:
20s is for you to settle down

Everyone told me to settle down
Get done with my education
Get married
Have kids
Buy that house, car
Settle down

If you didn't you never would!

I now realize that these 13 things the world told me in my 20s, were LIES!

I intend to stick to these principles for as long as I enjoy living them.

Thank you all for your support.
I am where I am because you cared, you engaged, you gave me feedback and you held me accountable.
I wish I could meet you all and give you a hug :)

Tldr:
1. Be consistent
2. Be vulnerable/real
3. Be helpful
4. Be authentic
5. Be giving
6. Be gracious
7. Be empathetic

This isn't a list for just content.
This is a list for life!

I have often found myself better, if I listened to the message objectively, instead of focusing on its tonality.

https://t.co/Q9yEIUnaw1

7. Be empathetic

But, you don't control everyone.
There will be trolling.
There will be people who will come at you.

Remind yourself, they must be going through something really hard in their life, to shit on others!
Don't be angry at them.
Be sorry for them.
Be empathetic!

6. Be gracious

TW is considered a rather toxic platform, but that isn't how I wanted to play the game.

So no punching anybody, no calling out names, no dismissal of anyone or anything (except FDs ofcourse).

If I'm civil in my conduct, maybe it inspires someone else to also be.

It needn't be in a monetary form.
Instead, it needs to be in the form that is most authentic to you.

For example, I love how @SahilBloom is perpetually extending support.
He is the biggest cheerleader on the platform.
He gives, through his support!

5. Be giving

A big part of my authentic self is that I love gifting.
I genuinely love gifting.

So I chose TW as my gifting abode :)

Gifting books, kindles, random surprises - anything to make people smile and happy, thus selfishly making me happy.

This thread is one of the poorest performing thread.
And one of my favorites.
This thread is me.

In my first book, I reproduced it exactly the way it is - and I am surprised how many people called it the best part of the book :)

https://t.co/rIhY0qaXpY

4. Be authentic

A strong pillar of my life is being authentic.
I am who I am - whether you see me on YT, TW, in the mall or at a restaurant.
You will find the same person.

On TW that meant, sharing things that I care about as against things that people would want to know.

Choosing who to help, is just as important as choosing to help.

https://t.co/D0JdWj7X15

3. Be helpful

Help never goes into an abyss.
It might only when we expect something out of the help we extend.

I wanted to be helpful to those in their 20s.
Which meant that my content will, by design, not appeal to everyone.
And that was a choice I was willing to make.

But that required me to also boldly share my failures, since they were such a huge part of my life.

Whenever I did, people didn't someone who had won every single time.
They found themselves, who might be failing, but could rise up again.

https://t.co/bOkugpKShS

2. Be vulnerable

I am lucky I started creating content at the age of 40, by which time I had changed careers, started companies, made a LOT of mistakes and learnt a lot reflecting upon them.

Sharing my life's learning became the easy (and perpetual) content source.

Until Mar 2020, and I decided to double-down on content.

Apr 24, 2020 I wrote my 2nd thread.
And have been writing a thread every Friday since then.

Its not the everyday tweeting that defines consistency.
Its the rhythm you establish in your community's mind, that defines it.

1. Be consistent

I joined TW in 2009.
Consumed it (as a confused soul) until 2017
Then I began to sporadically contribute.
In 2019, on my 39th birthday I shared a thread that was received well.
https://t.co/8kxmfZ3oHA
I treated it one-off and went back to my sporadic tweeting.

I recently crossed 500K followers on TW and sat down to reflect what made it happen.
Its certainly been the hardest platform to crack, but not surprisingly, the principles that worked elsewhere worked here too.

7 simple, yet powerful principles that helped me get to 500K followers on Twitter.

We learn it on our own and often the mistakes can be lethal or the side effects long lasting.

I hope these 25 pieces of advice that I realized over my career, help you build a successful one for yourself :)

It is baffling how we spend ~20 odd years preparing for a career, but are not given even a year's equivalent of training on how to navigate it in real life.

Our school and college often does such an inadequate job teaching us about the real world.

Solve problems

Those who solve problems will be rewarded more than those who maintain the status quo.

Use your 20s to explore
Your 30s to build upon the thing you are best at
Your 40s to financially retire

You don't find your passion!
It is not lying around to be discovered.

You grow your passion.
By exploring.

Your network is your opportunity generator.

Your colleagues will go on to do wonderfully different things.
How you treated them will determine the quality and quantity of opportunities that come through them.

Your boss matters!

You will learn far more from a competence manager who is strict with you and gives you harsh feedback, than an incompetent manager who is always nice to you.

Be nice to people.
Help people.

The bigger the audience who like you, the more people will take you seriously.

College does not train you for work.

College teaches you and then tests you.
Work tests you and then teaches you.

Early on, don't say 'it's not my job'.
Later on, let people do their job.

Don't be afraid to take a pay cut, for the right experience.

That gap will be covered faster than you think it will.
If you are not happy doing it, you will never be the best at it!

Toxic jobs do exist.
Where there is no respect or recognition, no progress, no role models for you, no personal space and no/poor financial incentives.

Most people are in because they have little or no choice.

Almost all tie-breakers in an interview process are won by the more likeable candidate.

Smile during interviews.

If all leaders in the company engage in politics, then it is not politics.

It is the culture.

If you hustle, you grow fast in the short term.
If you pace yourself, you grow big in the long term.

Feedback is not given.
Feedback is sought.

Those who seek it, embrace the truth.

The corporate world lays a trap by offering you perks and privileges.

It wants to see who feel entitled to it.
Those are the one who will rarely win!

No job is 9-5, or 10-6 or fixed hours.

Your job is the amount of focused time you spend on it.

The reward for standing by your promised word is immense.

Once you have made a commitment, no one should need to follow up on you.

Action >>> Thought

No one gets rewarded for 'I had the same idea'.

Early on in your career, go deep in whatever you do.

Later on in your career, go wide.

If you have 5 years of work experience, then make it 5 YEARS of experience.

Not 1 year of experience done 5 times.
You grow professionally by making your boss' life easier.

Because someone is good at their work does not mean they will become good managers.

Managing oneself is very different from managing others.

Eventually, every role ends up about managing people.

Every role.

Early in your career you get paid for what you can do.

Later you get paid for what you do.

25 career advice, that I wish we were given before we started our jobs.

That exam, that interview, that relationship, that money does not define you.
Your feelings today do not define you.
Your result today does not define you.

You are much bigger than this :)

So many of you know what I am talking about.
You have already 'failed' these tests and yet, you are still here!

In many ways you are perhaps grateful that you did not clear that exam, that college, that interview.

Because it opened up new paths for you to venture on.

The truth is - that exam, that job, that salary, that relationship, that house, that car, that bank balance - is not the destination.

These are all means to get to a point in life where we wish to go.
There are a million ways to get to that point.
https://t.co/GrPv5AAbrY

And if there is only one thing that I can tell you at this moment, it is that life IS NOT over.

That just isn‚Äôt true!

I know exactly how it feels to let your parents down.
To let yourself down.
To be clueless as to what to do next.
To think that life is over!

Hundreds of thousands of students in India go through this every year.
Not clearing CAT/NEET/UPSC/IIT/CA and what not.
Not making that dream college.
That dream company!

I often get emails from those who did not clear the exam, or know they will not clear the exam.

Devastated!

My roll number is not there.
I rub my eyes, shake my head, and start from the top again.
My roll number is not there.

In that moment, my life felt like it was over!!

On the day of the result, I go to the IIT Delhi campus with my dad, on our Bajaj Super FE Scooter.
Walk to the notice board where the roll numbers are displayed.

And start moving my finger from top to bottom.

The year is 1998.

I have just given my IIT-JEE exam after class 12th.
And I was confident that I would make it to the top 1000 ranks.

Follow me on @warikoo for my weekly thread on life, failures and productivity.
Simply because you too may find yourself exhibiting these same toxic behaviors in another relationship.

The key then is to abstract the behavior from the person. 

Work on the behavior. 
Not on the person. 

‚ÄòThis behavior is toxic for me‚Äô as against ‚Äòyou are a toxic person‚Äô

We often call people toxic. However it is behaviors that are toxic. 

Two equally wonderful people could still be toxic for each other, if these behaviors are triggered (for any reason whatsoever)

10. Making you feel you are walking on eggshells 

If you blame people for speaking the truth, then what will remains are only lies.

9. Believing they are the central character in your story

You are the central character only in your story. 
As is everyone else in theirs.

8. Telling you that you aren‚Äôt doing enough 

Making others responsible for your happiness is not interdependence. 
It‚Äôs lack of self awareness.

7. Asking a question and then judging you for your answer

Asking questions without being ready to hear any answer, isn‚Äôt curiosity. 
It‚Äôs an imposition.

6. Bringing your past mistakes into present conversations

Reminding one of their past mistakes isn‚Äôt helpful. 
It‚Äôs blaming.

5. Having a problem for every solution 

Constantly questioning the efforts of others to advance isn‚Äôt realism. 
It‚Äôs cynicism.

4. Asking for boundaries but not respecting yours

Setting boundaries isn‚Äôt an exercise in defending yourself. It‚Äôs an exercise to include everyone.

3. Making you feel guilty if you share feedback

Controlling who and how gives feedback, isn‚Äôt seeking feedback. 
It‚Äôs seeking power.

2. Blaming you for their unhappiness 

Happiness, if dependent on external factors isn‚Äôt happiness. 
It‚Äôs irrational hope.

1. Apologizing but doing nothing to change 

An apology without any action isn‚Äôt an apology. 
It‚Äôs manipulation.

10 Toxic behaviors that people exhibit.

I am tired of knowing nothing and being reminded of it all the time.

- F Scott Fitzgerald

Of course, the title of this thread is designed to be sensational. None of these facts are things you do not know already.

What warrants this thread then, is the fact that despite knowing these facts we tend to repeat the same mistakes.
Over and over again.

Hence, a reminder.

20. Being calm is a skill

We are born to react.
Training ourselves not to, take time, practice and intent.

19. If you do not care about people's validation, you will get it automatically.

You will make your best friends, when not looking for one.
You will find your soul mate, when not searching for one.

18. If people like you, life becomes easier.

Be kind!

17. Crave for feedback, not admiration.

Admiration makes you believe you are right.
Feedback shows you how you could be right.

16. That thing that you were scolded for as a kid could be the thing you are praised for as an adult.

Do not take the world's assessment of you as a kid, as the truth!

15. We were all born with different capabilities.
But there is no limit on how much we can grow from what we had.

14. The more you give, the more you‚Äôll get.

But don't give with the expectation of getting.
That is not giving.
That is a transaction!

13. Pro is the amateur that showed up everyday.

99% of success is just showing up.

12. Whatever you are feeling today, will eventually fade away.

Do not take permanent decisions based on temporary emotions.
12. Love and time heals everything.

11. Buying things is expensive.

And it is not money that I am talking about.
It is the need to show off.
The addiction.
The indulgence.
The treadmill which you cannot get off, the one that tells that you have to keep buying things to be happy.

10. Even the work you thoroughly enjoy, will suck some days!

Your job is not to find work that is awesome everyday.
Your job is to find work that you find awesome most days.
Your work should not suck!
If it does, reflect on the reason you are still in it.

9. Relationships should make you a better person.

And yet we continue to suffer in relationships.
Even the ones we chose for ourselves.

8. Excuses do not make us grow.

We promise to do something, but we could not.
So we come up with an excuse.
As if an excuse is equal to getting the work done.
They do not.
They just make us feel we are not in control.

7. Failure is NOT the stepping stone to success.

Everyone fails
But not everyone succeeds.
Between failure and success lies reflection.

A failure not reflected upon, is a failure wasted!

6. Nobody is responsible for our life.

We bear the consequences of our actions.
We are responsible for our life.

Your worst enemy is the one who convinces you that your life sucks because of someone or something else!
That enemy could be you!

5. You and your friends will change.

You will become different people.
You may not relate to them anymore.

It is ok to move on.

4. Our parents are not always right.

They are humans first, became parents later.
And no training taught them how to do the job well.
They learnt along the way.
Made a lot of mistakes.
And still continue to.

Forgive them.

3. We are not the only ones confused.

We are not the only ones struggling.
We are not the only one not sure of ourselves.

Everyone carries a load.
We just see ours.

2. People do not expect us to be rich. They expect us to be kind.

Yet we spend far more energy trying to come across as rich, as against kind!

1. We are not the center of everyone's life

We are the center of our life. Just as people as the center of theirs.
Our lives intersect. They do not rule over each other!

20 CRAZY facts about life

It's ok to feel stuck, feel demotivated, feel like nothing is working out for you.
We all go through this.

And we all find ways of dealing with it eventually.
You will be ok.
Everything will be ok.
It's ok!

Hugs :)

It's ok to say sorry.
It's not ok to wait for the apology.

It's ok to fail. 
It's not ok to be ashamed of it.
It's ok to not know the answer.
It's ok to say no.
It's ok to want to be happy, instead of rich.
It's ok to ask questions that you think are too dumb to ask.
It's ok if everyone doesn't like you.
It's ok to not want to hustle 24/7.
It's ok to cry.
It's ok to tell someone that they make you uncomfortable.
It's ok to move out of your parent's home, in order to save the relationship.
It's ok to not want to go to work today, because you are just tired.
It's ok to not want to do what you did in college.
It's ok to feel as if you don't understand your parents anymore.
It's ok to not want to grow up.
It's ok to want to dance on your favorite song, irrespective of where you are or who you are with.
It's ok to smile at strangers.
It's ok to fall out of love because you were the only one who kept giving, and you had only so much to give.
It's ok to not reply to a text, because you have nothing to say.
It's ok to want to be left alone, yet not want to feel lonely.
It's ok to take your time to figure out life.
It's ok to let go off your childhood friends, because they bring you down now.

It's ok!

I am giving away these 7 books. 

How to claim?
1. Follow me (open only to followers)
2. Reply to the tweet of the book you want to be gifted

7. The Little Book of Stoicism: Timeless Wisdom to Gain Resilience, Confidence, and Calmness
https://t.co/Z5KWtRQl7E

A brilliant introduction to stoicism, that teaches you how to deal more effectively with whatever life throws at you and live up to your best self.

6. Sapiens A Graphic History: The Birth of Humankind Vol. 1 + The Pillars of Civilization Vol. 2
The illustrated version of the book Sapiens. Stunningly done! Highly recommended

https://t.co/c9G4MSmuBb

5. Destinations of a lifetime
https://t.co/9E8ZWzraNi

This is eye candy when it comes to books. 225 of the world's most amazing places. 
Yummy :))

https://t.co/cZqzDrcdRt

PS: I spoke to Seth Godin recently about the book 
https://t.co/sczGTGRD9b

3. The Carbon Almanac: It's Not Too Late
https://t.co/OT2mQPoFD7

A brilliant book on climate change and how you can bring about a movement, NOT at an individual level, but instead at a system level.

2. Poor Charlie's Almanack: The Wit and Wisdom of Charles T. Munger
https://t.co/L3Z4mGeEJb

A breathtaking book about the life and lessons of Munger (Warren Buffet's partner all along).
Not just for finance enthusiasts, I say this is a must for life enthusiasts.

1. Seeking Wisdom: From Darwin to Munger
https://t.co/0UmG2zRDpm 

This book is frankly the only book one needs to read, if they could only 1 book their entire life. 
Exceptional in its details and exhaustive in its coverage.

Chiki reminded me - if you can release 3 videos a week on YouTube, you can surely write a book a year!

Yes maam :)

We are not done yet.

A musical anthem on the theme of "DO EPIC SHIT" is on its way!

A book tour is on its way!

And the next book just got done - coming up December 2022. https://t.co/85WtW3PbWV

I didn't expect writing a book to be such a surreal experience. 

It has been immensely rewarding, it tested my skills and brought the best out of me and it gave me love and respect far beyond my wildest imagination! https://t.co/tu35FiDjg8

None of this would have been possible without one big thing: luck!

The success of the book cannot be claimed by me, nor can I explain it. 

This thread is to convince myself that I had some role to play :))

More importantly, there isn't a single day where I do not get an email/message stating 
'this is the first book we have read/finished'

Nothing makes me happier!

Today:
1. The book has sold over 200,000+ copies, making it one of the best selling books of the year.
2. It is already in 8 languages (English, 6 regional languages, Portuguese)
3. Acc to my estimate, 350,000+ additional pirated copies have been sold.

Did all of this work?

The book launched #1 on all possible spots. 
The 5,000 signed copies got sold out in less than 3hrs! https://t.co/UmrMGBH73F

Posts such as these became common and well-received

Imagine a reader's joy when they see something like this! 

PS: Shared with Rashmi's permission https://t.co/rsSRbO4v1d

Others saw the acknowledgement. 
FOMO set in.
They wanted the acknowledgement too.
So they too shared.
I acknowledged them too.
Others saw the acknowledgement.

The cycle wonderfully continued.

3. Engage with the audience talking about the book

This became the big game changer. Since folks were reading the book and tweeting/instagramming it, my job became to acknowledge them.

That was a big deal for them. They loved the acknowledge.

While signing, I also added some surprises. Because I knew they would come back to create a ripple effect.

And they did :) https://t.co/lU17K6XsUK

I signed 5,000 copies for them, so that they not only got the first copy of the book, but also something for keeps.

Took 2+ days to sign these copies. But I am so glad I did :) https://t.co/tTO4lviuxE

2. Capitalize on the current following that the personal brand had built.

The book was pre-launched on Dec 9th 2021 and I knew the early buyers would be the followers of Ankur Warikoo.

The book was also written in such a way that it made it very share-friendly on social media.

People clicked photos, proudly so!

People created their own stories around the 'story-less book'

https://t.co/XJXJJ0ESkr

So we made the book look really cute. 

I think its a stunning cover (thanks @Chikisarkar), its small in size and it really looks good in photos!

Photo courtesy: https://t.co/GA3nqSW1KQ https://t.co/FHwBU6U7m1

To make sure the book launched well and continued to sell well, we decided on 3 things:

1. Make the book instagrammable

The audience doesn't read, is surely spending time on Instagram.

If they did end up reading the book, I wanted them to feel a sense of pride.
And show off!

It was a gamble, which thankfully paid off.

Within a few months, the book was seen selling for Rs. 50-150 on the streets of India.

How do we know they were pirated?
Because all of them were paperback, while we only had a hardcover in circulation! https://t.co/BHIaJbxFi9

Because I knew that if the book does well, it will be pirated.
And the high cost of the book would make the cheaper pirated version look more attractive.

Plus pirated versions tend to crowd the roadside bookstalls and traffic lights.
The right visibility!

Problem #3: Books are considered expensive, as compared to cheap/free entertainment.

10 years of running Groupon/nearbuy has taught me a lot about pricing.
I played a game here.

We decided to release ONLY a hardcover and priced it Rs. 399.
For India, that is an expensive book!

I made the book super easy to read.

Spaced out words. Lots of empty space. 
While the book is 293 pages, it is technically no more than 150 pages.

So it was easy to read it.
And easy to finish as well, should one want to. https://t.co/aYfsG2FdNY

Problem #2: It requires commitment to finish a book

Since the book had no story, you technically didn't have to finish it!
Yay!

You could read a page and leave it. Or read 10 and leave it. 
And it would still (hopefully) help you in some manner!

I did one more thing...

We picked my best performing content for the past 3 years, created categories, bucketed the content pieces into those categories and went through 4+ rounds of intense editing, to make this 'story-less' book.

Huge shoutout to @nishthagehija26 for actually writing the book!

For this, the content had to be disconnected by design. 
I knew this would be extremely disconcerting to all genuine book readers.
But I wasn't writing for them.
Or to win any literary award.

My audience, I knew, needed a book that needed little attention to consume it!

Problem #1: It requires attention to follow a story.

I decided to not have a story!
The book would have no start and no finish. 
The inspiration for this was a game I used to play in school - book cricket.
Open a random page and the page number would be your score. https://t.co/P95qLGuKnx

My book, if it had to appeal to this segment, had to solve for these 3 core problems.

Here is how I did it...

I came to 3 reasons
1. It requires attention to follow a story.
2. It requires commitment to finish a book.
3. It is thus considered expensive, as compared to cheap/free entertainment.

But that wasn't easy. Because, by definition, they do not like reading or have never read.

So I asked myself this question, 'what are the top reasons they do not read?'

And it broke my heart to see that there were so many people, not just the younger generation, that rarely read books or had never read one.

I wanted to write for them.

I have benefitted immensely from books, all my life.

It is crazy that for the prize of a large pizza, I get to learn from the experience and caliber of someone else's life.

https://t.co/bcwC0LN1tr

...the question I had asked when I started my content journey.

'Who am I creating this for?'

In context of the book, the question was, 'Who am I writing this book for?'

She gladly agreed and in 2020 I signed my first ever book deal. 

Since this was peak-COVID, I asked for time to get the book together. I wanted people to be in the right frame to even want a new book in their hands. 

As I sat down to write the book, I went back to...

'are you writing a book?"

Strangely, I started getting approached by publishing houses as well, with the same question.

I remembered Chiki's remark and sent her an email. https://t.co/GZu3ZokwS0

Fast forward 2020
March 2020 I put a team together to give content creation a more organized and dedicated shot.

By end 2020, it was evident we were doing something right. The brand has grown fast and thankfully with a lot of love.

A question that kept surfacing often was...

Sorry what?!?

While I had writing a blog for 10+ years at that point and I genuinely loved writing, I had never seen myself as an author.

So I frankly felt that she was being really nice. I thanked her and promised to stay in touch.

2015: @Chikisarkar and I were on a panel discussion together.
I admit I did not know of Chiki before that. She ofcourse didn't know of me either.

After the session, Chiki and I exchanged contacts. 
And I see an email from her the other day. https://t.co/duvWcMW3e3

How my first book went on to become a national bestseller.

PS: I am on the move today, thus copied this from my weekly newsletter (sent out this morning). If you are subscribed to my nl, sorry for the repeat content :)

"3 things" is proven to be the best form of retention. 
2 or less is considered inadequate and 4 or more is considered an overkill (and too hard to remember). 

That is why my fascination with number 3, especially in my IG reels :))
3. For being who you are - you can apologize for what you have done, or what you shouldn't have said, but don't ever apologize for your identity, your existence.

3 things you should never apologize for‚Äã

1. For the clothes you wear - it is your choice, it is your life. Do not give anyone the power to shame you!

2. For ending a toxic relationship - you watched out for yourself and did the right thing.

3 tips to boost your confidence

‚Äã1. Dating - helps you forge relationships and be genuinely curious about others.

2. Approaching strangers - helps you get comfortable with the fear of being rejected.

3. Sending cold emails - helps you articulate and seek help objectively.
3. You still crave for people's validation. Until you do not hear good things about yourself from people, you don't feel good about yourself.

3 signs that you have a long way to go‚Äã

1. You get angry a lot. You feel that anger is a legitimate way of expressing yourself.

2. If someone says anything mean to you even for 30 seconds, you spend the entire day thinking about it.

2. Not thinking about your money. Not respecting it. Not investing it, so that it can work for you. 

3. Spending time with people who are like you. When you spend time with people like you, you learn nothing new. You just hear what you already know.

2. Don't judge people. I used to judge people who smoke, drank, thinking they are bad people. It is not what they do, but who they are within, that defines them.

3. Don't always solve problems. Sometimes all that one wants is for them to be heard.

3 relationship mistakes‚Äã to avoid

1. Don't be a people pleaser. The more your identity depends on what others think of you, the lesser you will be happy in your life.
3. They do not hold you responsible for their happiness. They do not say "why aren't you there for me, why do you not make me happy?" Instead, they ask "How can I make you happy?"
2. They always tell you the truth. Knowing that the truth will be hard, and you might not talk to them after that. Yet they state it, because it is the right thing to do.

3 things best friends do‚Äã

1. They are genuinely happy for your success. It is easy to be there when someone is sad, but it is intensely hard to be truly happy when someone else wins.
3. They always blame you if you are not there for them.

3 signs of toxic people
‚Äã1. They make you feel bad about who you are.
2. They make you feel guilty if they are sad.
3. Tell them something that you do not personally follow - essentially teaching kids that lying is a natural way of living.
2. Love the other child if the first one is angry - essentially teaching kids that if you do not listen to me, I will not love you. Thus spoiling their definition of love.

3 Mistakes parents make

‚Äã1. Hit the floor when the kid falls - essentially teaching kids that it is not their fault. They can always blame someone else.
3. Fundamental relationship rule: If you have to become someone that you do not like, in a relationship, then change the relationship, not yourself.
2. The 2-minutes rule: If something can be done in less than 2 minutes, get it done. Don't add it to your to-do list and pile up on that list.

3 Cool rules for life
‚Äã
1. The 30-day rule: If you really want to buy something, wait for 30 days and ask yourself if you still need it. Chances are you won't need them anymore.
3. Remove those who suck energy from you

3 Selfish ways to live

‚Äã1. Say no to people - the more you say no to people, the more you will say yes to things that are important for you.

2. Make your happiness your no. 1 priority - until you are not happy, people around you will never be happy around you.

3 tips for life

Do not save what is left after spending, but spend what is left after saving. 

‚Äì Warren Buffett

Build income streams beyond your core job

1. Invest
2. Start a business
3. Create intellectual property
4. Build a personal brand
5. Freelance
We live in a world of unprecedented opportunities.
Make the most of it.

Bonus Hack:
Saving money will not get you too far. The key is to focus on your income.

Here is the truth:
To survive, you have to spend a certain amount. You can't (and shouldn't) go lower than that. There is a cap.
But your income has no cap!

Hack #13
Use deals/discount platforms whenever you can

There is no shame in using coupon codes, or buying vouchers to save money.
It is your money!
Be smart about it.

Till date I get emails from users who saved thousands in a year using nearbuy.

...No more than 30% towards your wants (gadgets, vacations, indulgent fashion etc)
and atleast 20% towards investments

This might help
https://t.co/IB8fNwiwTN

Hack #12
Create a budget

Boring...! But it works.
Please prepare a budget for your expenses - your needs, your wants, your investments.

For ex:
50:30:20 is a good rule to start with.
No more than 50% of your income towards your needs (EMIs, food, utilities etc)...
...you get 40 years of cover and STILL end up paying lesser premium, than if you were to buy the same cover at age 35 (and only get cover for 30 years)

Hack #11
Buy life insurance early on

When young, the premium amount is much lower, because you are healthier with lesser chances of death.
And you lock that premium for the entire period.

For ex:
If you buy insurance at 25, until 65...

Hack #10
Pay off your loans faster

Just because you have a 25-yr home loan, doesn't mean you take 25-yrs to pay it off.

For ex:
1 extra EMI/year (so 13 instead of 12) + increase EMI by 10% every year, reduces a 25-yr loan to just 10yrs!
You save 60% on your interest amount!

Hack #9
Use incognito while buying online

I have no way to prove it, but I have seen prices go up if I keep searching for items online, be it flight tickets or even products on Amazon.

Use incognito to make purchases online.

Hack #8
Buy bigger sizes

Bigger sizes tend to be cheaper, on a per unit basis.

For ex: Water 500ml is way more expensive than water 20L can.
(On that note, please don't buy water!)

If you have the space to store, go for it.

Hack #7
Rent, if you need it occasionally

Don't buy things you wouldn't use frequently.
For ex: I rent my camera lenses. The lens I prefer are insanely expensive (5L+) and I pay peanuts to use them for at most 7 days a year!

Hack #6
The 30-day rule

If you really want to buy something, wait for another 30 days.
Chances are high you would not need it after 30 days.

Hack #5
Use shopping lists

Even if you are shopping online, make a list.
A list is proven to make us stick to it, as against window shop and start drifting.

Hack #4
Use credit cards, ONLY if you have 100% of the money

1. You get an interest free loan (30-45 days). If your credit card spend is a lot, park that money in a debt fund and earn some free money (for doing nothing!)
2. You build your credit rating
3. You earn reward points

Hack #3
Use UPI instead of credit cards

1. Credit cards give the illusion of money, which you may not have. So we tend to overspend.
2. UPI is free (a lot of places still charge a surcharge on credit cards)
3. UPI is money you have. So you tend to spend accordingly.

Hack #2
Try a non-spending day

We don't realize how we end up spending everyday, even when we do not need to.

Try "fasting" with your money.
Once a week/fortnight/month - do not spend on anything.

This will require preparing in advance, which is why this hack works so well.

- Open a separate investment account. As soon as your salary hits, sweep your investment amount to that account.
Park your emergency fund, your SIP installments, your lumpsum investments there.

Basically, automate your investments!

Hack #1
Automate your savings

If we have money in the bank, we tend to spend it.
So move money out of your bank account.

For ex:
- Sign up for as much EPF deduction as you can, so it never even reaches you, but continues to compound.
- SIPs (and don't stop them!)

13 clever hacks to save money

Not all of these will be true for you.
Not all of these will even apply to you.

Consider them, as someone's life experiences being shared. 
For you to help build your own experiences.

20. People will judge you. Let them.

People judge because they want to feel good about themselves. 
It has nothing to do with you.
It is their insecurity.

18. Whatever you are feeling today, will fade away.

No feeling is permanent.
Do not act on them, as if they are.
17. If life feels like shit, take the smallest step possible to get you out of the moment you are in.

16. Be okay with being different than everyone else.

You are not them.
They are not you.

Until you aren't at peace with who you are, you will always crave to be someone else.

15. Stop trying to enjoy being around people, if you don't.

If you are comfortable in your own company, that is the best company!
14. You need to learn how to be an individual outside of your family.

13. Discover religion on your own.

Religion is a personal journey.
Explore the definition and importance of god all on your own.

12. Don't try to win conversations.

The energy and effort required to do so is massively more than the temporary high you get after winning one.

Learn to let go.

11. Spend time alone.

The toughest person to spend time with is you yourself.
Once you can co-exist with your own thoughts, everyone else becomes easier.

10. Set your boundaries.

Identify the non-negotiables in your life and communicate that to your people.

If you do not respect your boundaries, no one else will.

9. Learn what triggers you negatively.

The understanding of what triggers you is an essential input to the rest of your life.

8. Be responsible for your happiness.

If you make other's responsible for your happiness, you are rarely going to be happy.
7. You will always be scared of losing what you have, if you got it by luck and never reflected on how did you.

6. You will experience the joy of true love only if you first love yourself.

Else your partner will exhaust themselves trying to convince you that you are capable of love.

5. Don't rush into a marriage.

Who and why you decide to spend your life with - is one of the biggest decisions you will make in your life.

Don't take (almost) permanent decisions based on your early temporary emotions.

4. Set a routine.

A routine doesn't mean waking up early.
Or leading a boring life.

It means building the habit of discipline. Discipline of finishing what you had set out to do, by the time you had promised yourself.

3. You have time.

When young, the best thing is that you have time.
Time to figure things out.
Time to recover from impacts.

The pressure to figure things out early, is frankly self-inflicted.

2. Don't be in a rush to grow up.

Growing up is hard.
And there is no escape - you WILL have to grow up.
Don't be in a rush to settle!

1. It is ok to outgrow your school friends.

Especially if haven't grown as much and keep saying "you have changed so much", which is their attempt to slow you down.

20 things I wish we were told in our 20s

Holding on to anger is like grasping a hot coal with the intent of throwing it at someone else; you are the one who gets burned.

- Buddha

There is often irreparable and I would argue unnecessary damage that anger causes.

Save yourself the damage.
Save yourself the anger.

The trick is: has you mind done this enough times to know what to do this time around? 

Your brain is a muscle.
Just as you are not surprised anymore at how rapidly your brain brings back memories from the past to help you in the present, you won't be surprised at this either.

A lot of you may be left thinking 
"In that moment of rage, it is impossible to go through all of these steps. In that moment, you simply want to shout."

In written form, this looks like a long drawn sequence of affairs. 
In reality, all of this happens in milliseconds.

The second you realize what that need is, anger goes, ‚Äúoh cool - you remember? Awesome. I am done. I will now go back to chilling. Have a good day, you lovely.‚Äù

And anger will be gone!

To prepare you for it. 
To make you realize that this need is unfulfilled. 
And that the person opposite or this situation you are in, is provoking it. 
Do something about it. 
Anger is shouting at you, ‚ÄúDO YOU REMEMBER THAT NEED OF YOURS?‚Äù

How does identifying this unfulfilled need help my anger? 

Go back to where we started. 
Every emotion is there to serve a purpose. 
Anger‚Äôs purpose is to warn you. 
And get you to defend yourself. 
You realize that your unfulfilled need is surfacing. 
And anger is activated.

Step 3: 
Understand your anger

All anger stems from an unfulfilled need. 
Uncover that need. 

How?
That is a personal journal. 
For some it could be through writing a journal. 
For some through a conversation with themselves. 
For some through therapy.

This step takes time and practice.

There will be enough moments during the day where you will begin to feel the anger emerge. 

Don't get angry.
Begin to observe it.

Start with the small incidents, where it will be relatively easier to let go of the anger.

Meditation helps here immensely.
Meditation is like sitting by the road side watching cars go by.

Anger is one such car. 
You see it, you see what‚Äôs inside, you notice its color, its speed, its make. 
But you don‚Äôt stop it, or get onto it. 
You simply watch it go past you.

Step 2:
Count till ten and take deep breaths.

It sounds funny, but it works. 
Calm down. 

DO NOT react in that moment. 

You have, already won half the battle by recognizing you are about to get angry. 
You are already an observer. 

Now let that anger go past you.

Step 1:
Recognize that you are about to get angry.

Anger is a strong emotion. 
We all know how it feels. 
We can all sense it even before it comes.
We just let it flow, because in that moment, we WANT to get angry.
But remember, we don't HAVE to get angry.

How do you eliminate it? 
You can't.

We can't eliminate anger.
We can only manage it.

Here is an approach that might help.

You get angry because someone picks up the phone while in a conversation.
Not because of the phone.
Instead because of your unmet need to be heard, to be respected.
You do not want to be just some random person!

You get angry whenever someone tries to control you.
Not because of the control.
Instead because you were controlled as a kid, and you hated it. 
Your need to be free, is what makes you angry!

THAT feeling made you angry. 
Not the lying. 
But the feeling of feeling stupid.

On the surface it may look like that someone lied and it made you angry. 

However, when we scratch the surface, we may find that we felt stupid to have believed the lie. 

And feeling stupid is something you do not want to ever feel!

All our emotions serve a purpose.

Anger, for instance, surfaces when a very important need of ours is not met.

3 simple steps to manage your anger.

3. Before you invest, ensure you have
> Emergency fund of min 6+mths and ideally 12mths
> Health Insurance for you and your family
> Life Insurance, for all earning members of the family

2. You need stable income to invest
One-off or lumpsum investing might not work, basis when you invested. 
Regular (ideally monthly investing, otherwise called SIP) ensures you average out the highs/lows of the market

What are the risks involved in stock market investing?

1. Short term risk
If you wish to invest for less than 5 years, this may not be the right approach, because the market might give you poor returns

For ex: Rs. 100 invested in Sensex in 2017, would still be Rs. 100 in 2020!

What this approach ensures?
1. Relying on experts (Mutual Fund managers) 
2. Done in the most economical manner (Index Mutual Funds are mostly low cost)
3. Manages your risk, while delivering returns
So depending on your risk profile, here is what I would suggest as the mix of your stock market investing. https://t.co/FVVdSA0LS0

Rs. 100 invested in 2013 would be today:

Large Cap: Rs. 292
Mid Cap: Rs. 545
Small Cap: Rs. 888 https://t.co/76oM9O3eG6

Notice how when the market rises and falls, the large cap moves the least and small cap moves the most.

However, over a long period of time, small cap delivers more returns, while large cap delivers relatively lower.

Good news is that there are Mutual Funds for each of these segments

Ex: SBI Mutual Funds for all 3 (not promoted post) https://t.co/9Wfv4A3CWP

Large cap companies are far more stable, thus tend to not go up/down a lot.
However, because they are big, they tend to not grow as fast (in % terms). 

Midcap companies: relatively more up and down, relatively better returns

Smallcap: significant ups/downs; better returns

The stock market is divided broadly into 3 types of companies, based on their size.

Large Cap companies: Those valued at upwards of Rs. 20,000 Crores
Mid Cap companies: Between Rs. 5,000-20,000 Crores
Small Cap companies: Less than Rs. 5,000 Crores

How does this matter?

Irrespective of your risk profile, a good way to enter the stock market is buying a portfolio of stocks (usually called Mutual Funds)

Buying individual stocks requires a lot of research, analysis, time, which a beginner may not have.

These small percentages changes make a huge difference

1L invested for 20 years at 12% = ~8L
1L invested for 20 years at 15% = ~16L
1L invested for 20 years at 18% = ~32L

But the one getting 18% might see their value go down massively, before it rises up again.

2. Medium risk (ok with medium ups/downs, to get slightly better returns - around 13-15% annually)

3. High risk (ok with ups/downs as long as I get the best returns - around 15-18% annually)

How do you change the way you invest according to your risk profile?

To make it simple, pick one of the 3 risk profiles
1. Low risk (I do not want a lot of ups and down, and for that I am ok with lower returns - around 11-12% annually, as against 5% FD)

Mid-way summary:
1. Stock markets WILL go up and down
2. But over long term deliver much better results than other investments
3. So if you do not like the risk, please don't reduce the amount you invest in stock market. Instead, change the way you invest in the stock market.

If you are risk averse, you need to invest in such a way that the ups and downs of the stock market are minimal (called low volatility or low beta).

Not reduce the amount invested in the stock market.

3. Do not reduce the money you invest in the stock market. Instead, change the way you invest in the stock market.

This is important.
Most people who are not comfortable with risk, reduce the amount they invest in the stock market. 
That is the wrong approach.

If you are aged X, then (100-X)% of the monthly amount you invest, should be invested in the stock market (for the long term)

So if you are 25, you should invest 75% of your monthly investable amount in the stock market.

2. Ok, so the market goes up and down - does this mean you do not invest? NO!

It means you need to have a long-term horizon to investing.

A good approach for this is called the 100-X rule

However, the same Sensex over 10 years would show a different story.

This says if I invested Rs. 100 in the Sensex in July 2012, I would have Rs. 331 today!
Same money in
FD: Rs. 179
Gold: Rs. 187

Not too bad, huh? https://t.co/pnycgLuW8f

What does this graph mean?

That if you invested Rs. 100 in the Sensex on 2nd Feb, it would become Rs. 89 on 7th Mar, jump back to Rs. 102 by 4th April and today would be Rs. 96!

That is a LOT of movement in just 6 months. 
Not easy for everyone to digest.

1. The stock market goes up and down, a LOT!

On a daily/weekly/monthly/quarterly/yearly basis - your stock investments will go up and down, which could be unsettling for you.

This is BSE for last 6mths https://t.co/SIt96xArSX

Delivery is a great way to get started on your long-term investing journey. 

And if done in a way that understands your risk profile, it can be an immensely rewarding journey.

Trading is when you bet on the price movements of a stock and thus buy/sell (usually) within the same day itself.

It is:
1. Highly technical
2. Research/model driven
3. Not recommended for a beginner

Investing is when you buy stocks of a company (or a portfolio of stocks) and take "delivery" of them.
Which means you wish to keep them for the long term and not necessarily sell them right away.

Trading is different.

In this thread I will cover:
1. Difference between investing and trading
2. Prerequisites for stock market investing
3. Understanding your risk profile
4. Where to invest basis your risk profile
5. Risks involved
