In a world that benefits from your distraction, being focused is an act of rebel!

I would love for all of you to benefit from these tips that I have personally gained immensely from. 

Remember,
Focus in the new IQ

8. Do not try to remember anything
9. Restrict information to max 3 sources
10. Schedule time for these sources
11. Setup distraction time
12. Keep a journal for distraction thoughts
13. If anything can be done in 2 mins and needs to be done, do it.
14. Maintain a routine

tldr
1. de-clutter your mobile home screen
2. Put time limits on all apps where you tend to waste time
3. Remove all notifications and red color badges
4. Wake up slow
5. Maintain your glucose levels sideways
6. Find your max energy period
7. Use Pomodoro technique

14. Maintain a routine

Nothing beats distraction than having a routine. The absence of which is you willingly giving away control of your day to external stimuli.

Most of my day is free time. 
That is also part of the routine. 

https://t.co/UQ6sfh1D7e

13. If anything can be done in 2 mins and needs to be done, do it.

Our mind is designed to focus on things that we haven't finished, as against things that we have. 
Do not add to your pile of unfinished things.

12. Keep a journal for distraction thoughts

When we write we tell our brain that this is important.
Which is one of the best ways to get our mind off that thing.

So the next time you feel distracted, just write down that thought.

11. Setup distraction time

We crave for distraction because it is the forbidden fruit.
The dopamine is addictive. 

You could fight it by setting up scheduled time to "waste time"
Our mind then anticipates it, instead of craving for it.

I have three 30-min slots in my day.

10. Schedule time for these sources

Even with 3 sources, you could spend your entire day consumed by them.
Schedule time for them.

For example: I have set my email to hit my inbox only 3 times a day (using @Mailman_HQ) https://t.co/wxO1x2U6Gz

9. Restrict information to max 3 sources

We are living in a world of information abundance. And the more sources you have of information, the more you will constantly be consuming, as against doing real work.

I get all my information from only 3 sources:
Twitter
Emails
WhatsApp

> @NotionHQ (for note taking)
> @Baydin (for scheduling my emails, setting recurring emails, sending emails later etc)
> @Calendly (for maintaining my schedule)
> @WhatsApp (for note taking; I have a pinned group on top that just has me!)
> @asana (for all my work todos)

8. Do not try to remember anything

Your mind should be used to think.
Not to remember.
Use calendar, emails, notes app to record everything.
From todo lists, to reminders and beyond.

I use a list of tools to achieve this...

7. Use Pomodoro technique

A powerful way to keep your mind focused.
A 30-min slot is 1 pomodoro
25 mins of work
5 mins of break
Repeat
After 4 pomodoros, take a long 20-30 min break.

Download a pomodoro timer - there are plenty of good ones. https://t.co/DlFhYaSF6V

6. Find your max energy period

We all have a zone where we are most productive.
Guard that period ferociously. 
Schedule the toughest or most impactful things for that period.

For me, it is my mornings. 
Reserved for the most important things with most of it thinking time https://t.co/qIYhVj4xGo

If you can't afford one as yet, then be simply aware of what and how much you are eating.

Avoid excessive sugar, fried foods, packaged foods.

5. Maintain your glucose levels sideways

If our glucose levels go down, we feel drained out of energy.
If they remain too high, we tend to overeat.

I have started using a tracker (@Ultrahumanhq) for my glucose and its helped me immensely keep my energy levels steady throughout.

4. Wake up slow

One of the worst things we do to ourselves is to wake up just-in-time for our day.
We feel rushed.
It disorients us. For the entire day.

The first thing I do is to sip water for 15 mins.
No phone. No book. No music. No person.
Just me, water and my thoughts.

3. Remove all notifications and red color badges

You will not be able to fight distraction, if your mobile screen is constantly pinging with what's happening, or your screen shows you how many messages you have missed!

Remove all of them. It should look like this, all the time. https://t.co/5tHwpCsiE5

Bonus: 
Most of the time blocking apps allow for a password, through which you can bypass the time limit.

Set that password, but through your family/friends.
Ask them not to share it with you.

Thank me later!

2. Put time limits on all apps where you tend to waste time

Remember that we are trying to fight the best behavioral scientists in the world whose job is to keep us hooked to our apps.
Poor chance we will win.

Install time blockers!

1. de-clutter your mobile home screen

The mobile home screen is the biggest time sink of today. 
I realized keeping my home screen minimal dramatically reduced my tendency to check apps with no prime purpose. https://t.co/xQiOoTX7IL

14 ways to beat distraction.

These letters are easy to write, because they are in hindsight.

So here is the truth - these letters are not really for me.
They are for you.
You, who upon reading it feels "I needed to hear this today"
You, for whom this strikes a chord.
You, who felt it was written for you.

I am insanely lucky. So lucky that it shocks me at times.

So it might be easy to conclude that my life is one beautiful orchestrated and executed plan. 
It isn't. 

I consider myself successful.

But my success remained unexplained. 
I cannot justify it nor can claim it.

At 30:
Dear Ankur

You got fired from your startup. But you know you deserved it.
Think of this as a blessing.
To reflect.
To reassess.
To introspect.

And like always, believe in the habits you have set for yourself.

When nothing is certain, anything is possible.

At 29:

You are quitting consulting to become an entrepreneur. People think you're crazy, but you know what?
You can always come back to this, if things do not work out.
But this opportunity may never come again.

Who knows - this might be the opportunity that changes everything?

At 28:
Dear Ankur

You are lucky, man. Meeting Vivek one random evening and now working with him on https://t.co/OUUAhFATvc is so cool. That too along with your consulting job.

See how it works out. Do not put any pressure to make anything work.
Enjoy the exploration.

At 27:
Dear Ankur

You are getting married to the first woman you fell in love with.
Congratulations :)

Do not make her responsible for your happiness.
Make her experience your happiness.

At 26:
Dear Ankur

You are  lucky, man. You got through consulting. Staying in 5 star hotels, working with insanely smart people, getting paid a lot.

All of this will make you feel entitled.
Like you deserve all of this.
You don't.
You have to earn this.

Don't get comfortable!

At 25:
Dear Ankur

You are lucky, man! You got through ISB. Took a massive loan to get in. And now you are amongst super smart people.

You will feel worthless. 
But you can use this feeling to either paralyze yourself or elevate yourself.

The choice will always be yours!

At 24:
Dear Ankur

You are dropping out of your studies and coming back to India. You feel like a failure. You feel you have let everyone down. Your parents. Yourself.

But would you have made anyone happy by being unhappy yourself?

At 23:
Dear Ankur

You are where you always wanted to be. You are doing well in it. People envy you. You have it all.

But when you face the mirror and ask yourself if you are happy, you cannot lie to yourself.
You are not.

It is not the answer you wanted. 
But its the truth.

At 22:
Dear Ankur

Life is taking you to the US. You always wanted to go there. This is your dream coming true.

But this is not a goal, not a destination.
It is merely a milestone.

At 21:
Dear Ankur
You didn't make it to IIT again!
You feel worthless, incapable, inadequate.

You have no choice but to show up.
Show up again tomorrow.
And the day after.
And the day after that.

Pro is the amateur that showed up everyday.

At 20:
Dear Ankur
College may seem a waste often. That may be because you are looking at it from an education perspective.

Look at college from an experience perspective.

The purpose of college is not to find a job.
It is to find yourself!

At 19:
Dear Ankur
You have spent your entire life hanging out with people who are like you.

Go out and meet people who are nothing like you. Not to agree with them. Instead to see what do they know that you don't.

The world is far bigger and richer than what you know of it.

At 18:
Dear Ankur
All you want to do is to become a space scientist. It consumes every step, every thought, every purpose of yours.
It is awesome to have such drive at this age.

However, if you are driven by something else tomorrow, that's awesome too!

Things change.
Embrace it

21.  Your role is not to be the apple of the founder's or the CEO's or the manager's eyes. 
When you do what is stated above diligently, it eventually happens without you forcibly trying to!

19.  You do not become indispensable by wanting to be indispensable. You become indispensable by showing up and doing the hard things even when no one is watching.

20.  When you've made a mistake, own it up. And do not repeat it. Making a mistake twice is a mistake wasted.

17.  Nothing, absolutely nothing is a reason to be disrespectful to anyone. Be respectful. Always. Even while resolving conflicts.

18.  Let go of credit when you need it the most. It will fortify you as a human being.

13.  Never be overheard complaining. Not even to yourself. 

14.  Be on time. If you cannot be early.

15.  Start with trust. You will gain more of it when you give it away.

16.  Do not assume. Ask.

11.  When you commit to doing something, make sure people do not have to follow-up with you. 

12.  Make relationships at work. Be genuinely interested in people.

8.  Take notes. Do not try to remember everything (infact anything!). 
Carry a notebook. 

9.  Do not be driven only by money. 
Focus on learning velocity. Money will come as a by-product.

10.  Choose to deliver only A-quality work. Your work is your signature.

5.  Talk to people from different departments. 
Ask yourself "what do they know that I do not?"

6.  Get to know your colleagues beyond work. What drives them; what doesn't.

7.  Your role is first to learn and then to create impact. Not the other way around.

1.  Observe everything and everyone at your workplace. 
It educates you about the culture.

2.  Ask for specific feedback. Don't wait for it.

3.  Listen. More than you talk.

4.  Do not indulge in corporate politics. Stay away from places where it is encouraged.

I have in the past decade managed 1,000+ people directly/indirectly and have had the privilege of working with some extremely capable and driven individuals. 

Here are 21 things that I found as common traits in most of them.

21 ways to win at your job!

Awareness of these biases is the first step then.

"The eye sees only what the mind is prepared to comprehend."
- Robertson Davies

17. Blind Spot Bias
We don't think we have biases. But we see it in others.

Ex: "I am not biased."

16. In-group favoritism
We tend to agree more with folks in our group, than outside of our group.

Ex: "Ankur is from Delhi, so I like him more than someone from Mumbai. Because I am from Delhi."

15. Fundamental Attribution Error
We judge others on their personality or behavior, but we judge ourselves on the situation.

Ex: "Ankur is poor. He must be lazy. I am poor because I did not get the right opportunities."

14. Self-serving Bias
Our failures are situational, but our success is our hard work.

Ex: "I passed that exam because I worked hard. I failed that interview because I got late."

13. Curse of knowledge
Once we know something, we think that everyone else also knows it.

Ex: "I shouldn't share this content. Its so basic. Everyone knows this."

11. Gambler's Fallacy
We think future possibilities are affected by past events, even though they are independent.

Ex: "Ankur is tossing the coin and heads has come up 9 times. Now it will be tails for sure."

10. Sunk Cost Fallacy
We invest more in things that have cost us something, even if we face negative outcomes.

Ex: "Ankur is still holding on to that stock investment with a -80% return. Infact he is investing more."

9. Declinism
We tend to think that the past was better than the future will be.

Ex: "In our times, we had a lot more patience."

8. Framing Effect
We draw different conclusions from the same information, basis how the information is presented.

Ex: "Only 5% Indians invest in the stock market. There must be something wrong in it.
Only 5% Indians invest in the stock market. Imagine the potential."

7. Pessimism Bias
We tend to overestimate the probability of bad outcomes.

Ex: "I am sure I won't find a cab in time for the interview."

6. Ikea Effect
We place higher value on things that we have worked on ourselves.

Ex: "Isn't the cake awesome? I made it."

5. Zeigarnik Effect
We remember incomplete tasks more than completed tasks.

Ex: "Ankur continues to feel guilty that he hasn't finished those 2 tasks, ignoring that he has finished 10 others."

4. Survivorship Bias
We assume that the stories of those who survived, is the entire story. Because the "dead" are not there to share any story.

Ex: "So many unicorns being made every day. Entrepreneurship must be really awesome."

3. Status Quo bias
We prefer things to stay the same; change is mostly considered a negative thing.

Ex: "Ankur continues to be friends with toxic people, because they are childhood friends."

2. Third-person effect

We believe that others are more influenced by social media and mass media, than we are. 

Ex: "You are clearly watching a lot of news"

1. Spotlight effect
We overestimate how much attention people pay to our words and appearance.

Ex: Ankur is worried that everyone will hate his new shoes.

17 ways our mind plays tricks on us.

I found my rebel, through my rebellion.

As you can imagine, this template will not appeal to everyone. 
And that worked for me. 

It is a way for me to self select which company will appreciate someone like me, with my idiosyncrasies.

90% of companies rejected this.
I flourished at that 1 company that accepted me.

PS: On that note, here is the resume template I used for the longest time, while at ISB and beyond

https://t.co/OjAPM7Z99p

Caveat:
A true rebel isn't one who knows they are right and others are wrong.
A true rebel is one who is willing to take an alternate path and figure if it is right or not.

The world does not need another template.
The world needs a rebel.

We play a game designed by someone else. 
The rules of which have been laid out by someone else.

"Everything around you that you call life was made up by people that were no smarter than you and you can change it, you can influence it, you can build your own things that other people can use."

But most of us do not change the rules.

And whenever I think of templates, I am reminded of a powerful thing that Steve Jobs once said during an interview 

https://t.co/FlkVksSjnQ.

If Class tenth marks > 90%, then science
If parents = engineers, then study engineering
If parents = business, then study commerce
If engineer = yes, then MBA
If age > 25, get married asap
If married > 2 years, hav ekids asap

All of these are nothing but templates.

They are very seductive.
They give an illusion of safety.
They give an illusion of low risk.

So a lot of us fall for them.
Not just in our resumes.
In our lives.

Think about it.
How many of us are living our life like a template.
There is a thing about templates.

In a batch of 770 people, we had 380 students applying!

It made our job of shortlisting a lot harder, but we weren‚Äôt complaining. 
This is what we signed up for!
We eventually hired 4 product managers.
(all 4 of them stayed with us for 3+ years!)

We collated the frequently recurring names, and if they hadn‚Äôt applied reached out to them, while the submissions were on.
‚Äú7 students who have applied think you will be better than them at this role. Do you wish to consider applying?‚Äù

Very few will be able to say no to this!

Our motive was selfish.

1. As a startup, we were looking for those who could go beyond the stipulated mandates.

2. We wanted to see if we can get the most recommended students to also apply.

3. Does this approach not favor the creatively inclined? Why are those who have stuck to a format so far being penalized?

We sense nervousness.

2. Will naming someone else better than us, reduce our chances of getting an interview shortlist?

We sensed fear.

Students had questions. 
A LOT of questions. 

1. ‚Äúwhat does color mean?‚Äù
Do you mean actual color? 
Or ‚Äúadd color‚Äù figuratively?
This led to the most joyful submissions
PDFs
Comic books
Highlights

We sensed liberation.

1. Your resume SHOULD NOT be in the ISB resume template.
AND 
‚ÄúAdd color to it‚Äù 

2. On the resume, name someone else from the batch who you think is better than you, for the role you are applying for.

This was enough of a trigger, we realized!

The first time nearbuy (my previous startup) went to hire from ISB, we had to find a way of creating buzz on the campus.

We weren‚Äôt a well known brand.
We weren‚Äôt paying top salaries.
Competition for talent was intense.

So during our talk, we told students two things...

Templates are everywhere

Every Friday I write a thread on personal growth, failures, startups, organization building and more.

You can follow me on @warikoo to get them on your feed.

As we age, we feel less like leaves and more like trees. We have roots that ground us and sturdy trunks that may sway, but don't break, in the wind.

- Meg Jay, in "The Defining Decade"

And if you can learn from someone else's mistakes, then that's the best purpose that mistake served. 

I hope this thread acts as that for you.

And I know - I will continue to make them forever.

The key is not to get to a point where you don't make them anymore.
The key is to get to a point where you do not repeat them anymore.

I continued to make mistakes in my 30s

https://t.co/Bu8uo9RUkK

I made several mistakes in my 20s led by some of these rules.

https://t.co/jDCibrDBGV

They are not.

This world will do its best to impose these rules on you.
You have to do your  best to not believe them to be all true.
Instead, undertake this decade's journey to find out which ones work for you and which don't.

The 20s is quite a weird decade.

We are surrounded by the most people we have even been surrounded by.
And yet constantly feel alone.

And at 42 I realize that a large part of the reason are these self-imposed beliefs we live our 20s by.
A set of rules  that we feel are fixed.

"I should not lose my friends"

You will dread losing your friends.
You will dread being alone.
You will dread growing apart.
Even though you are not happy in those relationships anymore.

Truth is - you will outgrow your friends. It is ok to move on.

"I will become an adult one day"

We think there is a an age when we suddenly grow up.
And growing up means we have sorted everything out.
We know the answers to all questions.
We are in control.

Truth is - we will never have all the answers. That is life.

"I am going to change the world"

We all dream of something big, meaningful, purposeful for our life.
We pick that desire; make it into a goal. 
Only to be disappointed if it doesn't happen.

Truth is - the ones who change the world never set out to do so. They realized they had.

"I can always do that later"

We postpone things.
Calling that friend.
Quitting that toxic job.
Going to the gym.
Saying "I love you".
Following our heart.

We are in a hurry to win.
So we postpone living.

Truth is - life isn't a goal.
It is a day passing by, every single day.

"Health and sleep can wait"

We pull out all-nighters. Sleep odd hours.
Eat junk. Eat odd hours. Abuse our body.
Because we believe there is a tomorrow when we will fix everything.

Truth is - how we treat our body in our 20s is how our body treats us for the rest of our life.

"I have to be liked by all"

In our 20s, we crave for validation and acknowledgement.
We attempt to please all, because we believe that to be a way to win!

Truth is - we can never be liked by all.
Be yourself. The right people will come to you and stay.

"I need to find my passion"
 
We obsess over our passion.
Expecting it to be lying in some corner, waiting to be discovered.
And when we do, our life will never be the same again.

Truth is - we do not find our passion. 
We grow our passion.
And that's a long journey. For all.

"This year is make or break for me"

I remember feeling this way for every year in my 20s.
This year is when I had to do it.
Else I won't be able to.
The story repeated every year!

Truth is - in a 80yr life no one year has the power to impact your life, unless you allow it to.

"I want people to know I am successful."

You want that phone, that car, that salary, that brand - to look good.
You want people to talk highly of you.

Truth is - people's opinion about you don't make you successful.
Until you don't feel successful within!

"I am already old"

You set targets for yourself.
And then imposed timelines on them.
Which were frankly desires and had no basis.
So when you didn't hit them by the time you thought you would, you feel you have lost.

Truth is - you have time!
You're not old. You're early.

"I haven't achieved anything so far"

You will compare yourself to others.
Other's success will scare you, agonize you, mock you.
You will look at where you are and feel you are nowhere. 

Truth is - in your 20s your position doesn't matter.
Your direction does.

"I am stuck"

You will fail.
You will have self-doubt.
You will suffer.
You will experience pain.
You will feel paralyzed.
You will feel helpless.

Truth is - you are not stuck.
You can always take the smallest possible step to get you out of where you are right now.

"I need lots of money. NOW"

Most of us, especially those who grew up with lack of money, want to get rich. Quickly.
We optimize for that.
We run after money.
Fall for short-term gains.

Truth is - 20s is the decade to focus on your learning.
Money is then a side effect.

"I need to settle"

20s is the decade that the world tells us to settle.
Finish your education.
Get a job.
Get married.
Have kids.
Buy that house/car.
Settle!

Truth is - 20s is the decade to explore.
To find out what you are good at and what makes you happy.
To not rush.

"I am a loser"

All our lives, especially in our 20s, we feel we are the odd ones out.
Everyone else has it figured.
Everyone else is smart.
Everyone else is so certain.

There must be something wrong with us.

Truth is - everyone feels the same way!

STOP saying these things to yourself, in your 20s

A bad mentor tells.
A good mentor asks.
A great mentor listens.

Every time a 20yr old seeks me as their mentor, I find myself saying "you are a young warikoo making the same mistake that warikoo made."

I hope this thread is the start of fixing those mistakes.

Combine these 3 things
1. Seek mentors close to your experience levels
2. Seek multiple mentors for different areas
3. Seek mentors who are different from you

& it doesn't look so hard to find one.

Because now you are not looking for THE mentor.
You are looking for a mentor.

Lesson:
Seek mentors who are different from you.

They will show you a different side. 
They will ask questions you wouldn't ask otherwise.
They will make you a better version of yourself, not just a bigger version of yourself.

They are so different from me that every conversation with them is like opening myself to a whole new world.

They call me out, they are brutal yet honest, they care about me but do not use empathy to ruin me.

Fact?
Both of them are younger to me.

Until I realized, they see the problem the same way that I do.
What they have is experience.
What they lack is a different perspective.

Today, I seek people very different from me.
My mentors in entrepreneurship are 2 dear friends, who started up around the same time I did.

Mistake 3: I sought mentors who were like me

Humans are animals of association.
We love to spend time with people who are like us.
Who agree with us, endorse our point of view, think like us, act like us.

I sought the same from my mentors.

Lesson:
Have mentors. Several of them.

The ones who judgement you trust, in their field of brilliance.

Have one for career, one for money, one for relationships, one for anything you want in addition.

That's unfair.
It is too much pressure on one person.
You are setting them up for failure and yourself for disappointment.

Today, I have several mentors.
For different fields.
I am able to draw the best from the best.

Confession?
My best mentors do not even know me!

Mistake 2: I sought "the one" mentor

Growing up, I found it so fascinating that the most successful people always that this one mentor that changed their life.
That one guy who has stuck with them all along.

I wanted to find that one mentor.
The one who could solve everything.

Lesson:
Seek mentors who are slightly ahead of you.
Who would have recently experienced what you are going through right now.
Or have the rare ability to speak to you in a language you understand.

So,
1. They will rarely share it, thinking it's so obvious.
2. You will constantly feel like a fool, for not understanding them
3. The relationship is doomed!

If you seek a mentor who is far ahead of you, they will fail.
Because they wouldn't know whether is or isn't obvious to you.

They have experienced so much in life, that a lot of their learnings have been habits.
They do not realize they learnt it.
They live them now.

As a science student, I remember dreaming of Stephen Hawking as my mentor. 

I laugh at this today, not for the audacity but the foolishness of this dream.

Mistake 1. I sought "aspirational" mentors

If you wish to startup and I ask you, who would you want as a mentor, most will name the usual suspects.
The billionaires, the unicorn founders, the ones in the limelight.

That's the mistake I made as well.
Here are 3 big mistakes that I made early in my life, when it came to finding mentors, that I would love for you all to learn from.

Unfortunate are those who do not find the right mentors in their life.
Lucky are those who find them.
Harmed are those who find the wrong ones!

How to find the right mentors in your life.

"Life isn't about making relationships. It is about understanding why we make relationships."

Relationships define almost everything in our life.

They seem easy, but are not.
They feel permanent, but are not.
They appear trivial, but are not.

The more we understand them, the better we get at being happy with ourselves.

The one thing I learnt (and agree with) from the book "Courage to be disliked" is that every problem eventually boils down to interpersonal relationships. 

It is hard hitting at first to realize this, but the more you meditate on it, the clearer and obvious to becomes.

The most difficult person you will spend time with, is you yourself.

We don't spend time with ourselves.  
Because we are scared of what we might find. 

Your thoughts are your biggest strength, biggest enemy or biggest competition. 

You decide which role they play.

Some relationships will only suck energy from you. 

They do not know any better.
They need energy from everyone else, because they cannot generate it within.

These relationships are rarely give and take.
They only take.
And you have only so much to give.

The best friendships will be made when not trying to seek friendships. 

They will just happen.
It will feel like destiny.
You will never find your better half, if you don't think of yourself as a whole!

No matter how hard you try, you will never be able to convey the true depth of your love to someone else.

There will always be a gap.
Question is - do you continue compensating for it, or realize its true for the other side as well.
Your early excitement with a new relationship blinds you to their flaws, which will eventually be realized.

Over thinkers will never believe you when you tell them you will never leave.

Because their mind is always giving them reasons of why you will.

You will never be loved by someone who doesn't love themselves.

They do not know what it is to receive love, so they do not know what it is to love.

You are scared to let go of relationships, because you don't know how to make new ones.

That toxic friend, lover, even job - you hold on to them, because you don't trust yourselves to find it again!

You please people because you are terrified of facing your true self.

It's far easier to be nice to others and have them like you for it, then to meditate on your flaws and find out how much work you still have left to do on yourself!

You are in love with the idea of that person, not that person.

And when they behave like themselves, you feel disappointed, hurt, resentful.
But its quite possible, they have been that way always.
You just expected somebody else!

Your parents are going to die, and you have no idea when.

You do not have all the time in the world. 
Call them.
Tell them you love them,
Thank them.
Spend time with them.

https://t.co/rMNNGRisKk

Most relationships make you unhappy

They start off awesome.
But the early excitement eventually fades.
Flaws/differences emerge.

Remind yourself why you got into it in the first place.
To be happy!
If you still want the relationship, do whatever it takes to make it happy again.

13 harsh truths about relationships.

In my experience, the most successful professionals, across fields and industries, are the ones who have understood human motivation more than systems and processes. 

These tips come from their experience, their understanding.

A large part of our focus, while building a career, is on the technical aspect of it. 
The degree, the qualification, the years of experience, the interview, the appraisal process.

What we often miss is that the system has been designed by humans.
And humans never change!

A great way to set yourself up for success is to do more after you are finished doing what you were told to do.

Become positively unpredictable.
Do the right thing, even when no one is looking.

The search is not for the best paying job, or the best brand. 

The search is for a manager who believes in you more than you believe in yourself!

What you are supposed to do, is the output.
What you are supposed to achieve, is the outcome.

Own the outcome.

Never trust your memory. 

Write everything down.

It is much easier to be a commentator than a player.

But its the players that everyone is watching!

If you meet ALL expectations, you are doing your job at your level.

For you to move to the next level, you have to start  exceeding expectations.
Send your manager a weekly update on all that you did and where you need their help.

Early on in your career, pick a job where you learn the most, irrespective of the money.

Learning compounds faster than money!

Don't be in a hurry to create impact.
Be in a hurry to learn.
"I am a perfectionist" is the worst excuse for not getting the work done.

There's no such thing as "I can't" 

Either you don't want to. 
Or you need help.

People are more willing to help, when they know you will still do most of the work.

Seek help with the problem early.
Nothing makes you more indispensable, than doing what you committed to do, without anyone needing to check on you.
Spend time appreciating people, than waiting for them to appreciate you.
If you cannot write down what you wish to say, you do not yet know what to say.
Write your emails assuming they will be read by everybody.
If people can't trust you, it doesn't matter how smart you are.
In the end, every role boils down to how you deal with people.

Early in your career, you get paid for what you can do.

Later on, you get paid for what you know.

A few incredible lessons for your career

I realized this much later in life. Made so many mistakes with my money.

https://t.co/ydbPpMhjPM

The biggest tragedy of the world we live in, is how much of our life we spend thinking about money. 

The biggest joy of investing is that if done right, consistently and patiently, you can actually spend your life living and not thinking about money!

Your money works for you.

Here are some books that I recommend

The Intelligent Investor
https://t.co/HZVWCctMTC

The Richest Man in Babylon
https://t.co/KgUyMB8z2F

Psychology of Money by @morganhousel 
https://t.co/elSH1xqTUt

PS: If you open a demat account on Zerodha using the link above, I earn a brokerage income (no additional cost to you) - 100% of which is used to sponsor the education of kids that cannot afford it.

Last year we gave away 36L as support, which was 100% of our affiliate income.

I only buy 3 Crypto - Bitcoin, Ethereum and Solana.

I make my investments in the ratio of 100:10:1, so if I have Rs. 5,000 to spare I will buy BTC worth 4500, ETH worth 450 and SOL worth 50.

Bonus 7
If you can take some risk

Of the X that you invest outside of equity, put 2/3rd of it into fixed income (gold, bonds, EPF, PPF etc) and invest 1/3rd into Crypto.

I believe in its future, but please don't take my word for it.
Invest only if you are ok losing all of it.

These 6 steps, if clinically followed, can kickstart your investing journey. Key is to start. 

You will not know all the answers on Day1, but the journey will teach you a lot about how you view money and your relationship with it.

Just don't keep this money in the bank or an FD.

With inflation at 6% and taxes at (say) 20%, you need a return higher than 7.5% to beat inflation. 
So anything around 9-10% should be pretty good (real-estate, for higher income categories)

Corporate Bonds is another option (think FDs, but higher return and issued by companies).
They need to be very carefully vetted, because risk of losing all money is high.
Wint Wealth, GoldenPi do a good job.

PPF/EPF are also good options, but come with long-term lock-in.

6. Where to invest the rest?

You invested 100-X in equities. The rest should be parked in safer-lower-return assets.

Digital Gold (not jewelry) can be an option. 
Opt for Sovereign Gold Bonds; offers addn 2.5% return over and above gold price return.
https://t.co/D3TtwokxZL

Here are the returns of Nifty50 since 2000.

3yr return: 13.1%
5yr return: 13.5%
10yr return: 11.5%
20yr return: 15.1%

Again, plenty to chose from - HDFC, Navi etc https://t.co/Os05GlmBZ1

5b. Invest in an index fund
Picking standalone stocks is hard and requires expertise.
Index funds tracks the best stocks as a portfolio and for a very small fee you get an experienced manager to do it for you.

Nifty50 is a great index. It tracks the top 50 stocks of the NSE.

5. How much to invest in equity?

If your age is X, then 100-X should be invested in equities.
So 75% of your investment amt in equities, if you are aged 25. 

How?
5a. Open a demat account
There are plenty to chose from - Zerodha, Groww, 5Paisa, Upstox etc

4. Save ALL possible taxes

Once can (and should) save a lot of taxes by investing in assets that are deducted from our taxable income.

ELSS (equity-linked-savings-scheme), EPF, PPF, NPS, your insurance premiums - all fall under 80C deductions upto 1.5L/yr

Do these investments!

...this ratio should ideally keep changing every year.

So every year, if you get an increment in salary, or increase your income, turn the ratio around.

Allocate 50% of your increase to your investments, keep 30% intact for wants, and 20% towards needs.

I invest 30%/mth.

3. How much to invest every month?

Start with a basic 50:30:20 rule
50% of your monthly income towards your needs (EMI/Rent, food, utilities, bills etc) and no more.
30% towards your wants (phone, car, vacation, gadgets etc)
20% minimum invested.

However, with remote working...

Your emergency fund should be minimum 6X and ideally 12X of that amount.

Park 70% in an FD (make sure there are no charges to liquidate, when needed); 20% in your saving account and 10% in cash.

Build for this, before you start investing.

2. Build an emergency fund

Investing is a long term patient game. No point investing for that if you cannot manage emergencies in the present. 

Calculate your monthly expense for your needs.
EMI/Rent, food, utilities, bills.
Don't include investments and things you wish to buy.

Buy life insurance. 
NOT for investment; purely for protection. 
A term plan is the best in this case.

Take a cover that is minimum 15X of your annual salary and ideally 25X.
Take it until retirement age.

I have a 10Cr term plan, bought when I was 31 (I am 42 today).

So if average hospital cost per day is 10K/day, then buy a 3L cover for your family and a 4.5L cover for your parents. 

I have a 9L cover for my family and a 15L cover for my parents.

1. Before investing, protect yourself and your family.

Buy health insurance for your immediate family (spouse/kids) and a separate one for your parents/in-laws. 

Based on where you live, buy a cover that pays for 30days hospitalization for your family and 45days for parents.

Our mind can easily be tricked!

The question is, what do we trick it for?
Over 40+ years of existence, I have deployed these tricks to my advantage and can vouch for how massively effective they are, as compared to the effort needed.

17. Struggle to wake up early?

Set your alarm 10 mins earlier than your current wake up time.
Do it for 3 weeks.
Then 10 mins earlier.
3 weeks again.

Slowly work your way through to your desired wake-up time.

16. Struggle to quote your price?

Share a specific price, as against a round figure.
1.47 seems like a legitimate, thought-through number as against 1.5

15. Buy things and then regret?

If unsure whether you should buy it or not, wait for 30 days and then ask yourself if you still need the thing.
Quite likely you won't anymore.

14. Caught in office politics?

Compliment people behind their back.
The news will eventually travel to them.

People find it hard to fight people who compliment them.

13. Struggle to focus while listening to music?

Any song with lyrics will take our attention away. 
Instead, listen to instrumental music (ideally classical music).

12. Lose people's attention easily?

While speaking to them, include their name in your sentences.

We instantly react to our names, thus bringing our attention back to the conversation.

11. Struggle with procrastination?

Think of the task you have to finish, right before you go to sleep. Better still, think of the end of the task.

Your brain will mentally start mapping the path to finish it. Once up, this will make it easier for you to finish the task

10. Want to learn something?

Teach it to somebody else. 
It works, even if you are fake teaching (recording yourself, while you teach)

9. Feel under-confident?

Trick your mind with powerful reinforcements. 
Instead of saying "I think" or "I am not sure" say "I believe" or "I am certain".

8a: Bonus tip

Put time blockers on the apps you waste most time on.
Let your family/friend lock it with a PIN, which they do not share with you.

8. Waste a lot of time on the phone?

Schedule "waste" time on your calendar, just as you would schedule your productive hours.

Your brain anticipates it, looks forward to it and treats it as reward.

7. Struggle to invest?

Whenever you spend on anything that is a desire/wish (clothes, phone, eating out etc), transfer an equivalent amount to a separate bank account. 

This way you will enjoy your present, while planning for the future.

6. Want people to like you?

Repeat what they said, back to them.

"To make sure I heard you right, you are saying XXX (repeat what they said)"

They feel heard, they respect your listening skills - the mirroring helps.

5. Struggle to express gratitude?

Keep a gratitude jar

Everyday, before going to bed, write down something that you are grateful for.
Anything at all.

Place it in the jar.

In moments of weakness, go through the notes.

4. Struggle to manage your docs and thoughts?

Create a WhatsApp group with you and a friend.  
Delete the friend.
Now the group has only you. 
Pin the group to the top.

Use this group for sharing thoughts, capturing images, voice notes to yourself, whatever you want it to be!

3. Do not deal well with failure?

Practice failing.
Everyday, pick up a task that is not significant, but has a high chance of failure.
And do it.

Ask strangers for money.
Send cold emails.

Within 30 days, you will start dealing with failure a lot better.

2. People think you are self obsessed?

Whenever someone shares anything about their life, resist the urge to share your own experience around it, unless asked.

Avoid "me too", "I also do this", "I was thinking exactly the same".

17 life hacks you can start using today!

"You'll never change your life until you change something you do daily. The secret to your success is found in your daily routine."

- John Maxwell
Hit me up with any questions you have on this. Happy to answer through my experience and the little I know.

...they consciously chose to do the things that make them feel good, in a repeated fashion.

The most brilliant artists have what might look like no routine.
They wake up, do something, take a nap, wake up, do their work, go for a walk.

Might not look like a routine.
But it is.

A routine isn't discipline around tasks. 
It is disciple around emotions.

The most successful people have a routine.
That doesn't mean they are always working, or have things lined up back to back.

It means, they know which tasks make them feel what way.
And...

This video by @jordanbpeterson beautifully describes why we should all have a routine.

Short clip - give it a watch.
https://t.co/6QrgcZpQKd

Because I sleep early, I have consciously said no to a gazillion dinners and events.

That was a price I was more than willing to pay.
But it is still a price I have to pay.

And you will have to too.
Assess the price.
If ok, great.
If not, reassess the routine.

9. A routine will be costly. 

When you do things as per a routine, you are also in some saying no to spontaneity. 
That needn't be an entirely bad thing, but could feel bad often.

The emotional cost of sticking to a routine is high.

I used to read early morning.
Now I read right before I go to bed.

I used to play tennis and workout alternate days.
Now I do it everyday.

I used to meditate for 10mins (for 2+ years)
Now I meditate for 30+ mins 

Time you spend on yourself, is energy you give yourself.

8. You will change. Thus, your routine needs to as well.

A routine is not a destination.
It is a tool for you to become a better version of yourself.
And as you walk on that path, the tools you require will also change.
Be aware of that change.

I have been on this morning routine for 5+ years now, ever since I started actively meditating and playing tennis.

It took me 3+ years to go from 7am wake-up time to 430ish wake-up time (improving by ~10mins every 3 weeks)

7. Give it time

Routines are planned overnight.
They happen over years.
Be patient with them.

If you feel a sense of progress, you will need lesser and lesser motivation to persist.
Set no deadline to make a routine happen.

My wife, for instance, goes to play tennis at 515am (under the lights), while I meditate, sing and get the kids ready for school.

Once she is back, I leave for my tennis while she drops the kids to the bus stop and goes to the gym.

Works for both of us.

6. Do not have a routine in isolation

It becomes hard if your routine is in conflict with those you live with.

Bring them along.
Adjust if you have to.
Request them to as well.

What may seem like a compromise is still far better than not having a routine at all.

...ask yourself, how do these things make me feel?

The key is to do things for yourself, that give you energy, so that you have enough to dispense on things that you will have to do for others.

5. Measure progress in terms of energy, not goals

It is hard to quantify the impact of activities such as meditation, reading, walking, painting etc 
And thus its easy to conclude that they do not move you towards a goal.

That may not be the right metric.
Instead...

4. Schedule those things, as a process

Once you have identified the things that give you energy, set a process.
It may seem boring, clinical, robotic, but remember, these things give you energy.

You do not have to do them.
You WANT to do them.

3. Do things that GIVE you energy

The key to a routine, is to recharge yourself.
To gather energy.
Either from within or external sources.

For me, it is meditating and riyaaz (singing). 
For my wife, it is tennis and gardening.

Identify what it is for you.

Take your time to wake up.

What works for me is sipping a glass of water for 10 mins.
Just me.
No phone, no person, no book, nothing.

The key is NOT to activate all your senses instantly. 
Take it slow.

2. Wake up slowly

Kids are often a good reflection of how we should behave as adults.
How they wake up is something we should learn.

Kids rarely jump out of their bed.
They stretch, slowly open their eyes, don't start talking, instead reply in humming sounds.

Do the same.

1a. Try and have your meals at least 2 hours  and preferably 4 hours earlier than you sleep

1b. Try and not have any screen time for 30 mins before you sleep

1c. Try and not get your mind excited by any activity (for instance, thriller fiction books). Instead calm it down.

1. Sleep on time

The key to a morning routine, is to wake up the same time everyday.
The single biggest determinant of that, is your sleeping time.

If you sleep sporadically, you will struggle to wake up consistently at the same time.
Here are 9 steps towards building a morning routine, if that's what you wish to do

You can chose your time. 

Let nobody guilt trip you into waking up early. 
If nights are productive for you, build a routine around that.

It is far more important to have a routine for your day, than to force yourself to wake up early.

For the longest time, I was an inconsistent riser.

School was 6am (school bus was early), college was 7am (had to reach campus by 830), work was 8am (rushed to reach office by 9).

It was only when I became an entrepreneur, that I settled into a routine.
And I chose morning.

First, why does (any) routine work?

To have a routine is to train your mind and body on a repeated process.
Once the mind and body gets used to it, and begins to experience a sense of progress, it requires lesser and lesser motivation to repeat the same task.

Yesterday, in response to a question, I shared my morning routine on Twitter.

Post that I got a lot of DMs about it. Questions on how to build it, how does it work, why does it look so regimented etc.

I try and answer some questions in this thread.

https://t.co/6qxIbuX21s

Building a morning routine.

10. Maximize opportunities

Recall tossing the coin? 
You toss it enough times and you will get your desired outcome.

Problem is - people don't toss enough. Because that is a function of opportunities.

Build a system that generates opportunities endlessly -> luck is inevitable!
https://t.co/y5L2IgyJjc

Hear their stories, follow them, read them, observe them, question them.

They will teach you about luck.

Resisting doesn't mean not doing the obvious.
It means, your default is not to accept the obvious choice as the right choice.
Instead to explore more choices.

https://t.co/dae7TrnTK5

7. Resist the obvious

If you do what everyone does, you will most likely end up where everyone else ends up. 

To get lucky (or to have results different from others), you have to build a habit of looking into the non-obvious. 
And ask, where could that take me, if it works?

When I actively started creating content 2 years back, the only thing that I cared about was the process.

This process ensured that we reached 5.6Mn+ followers today.
Did I know we would get there in 2 years? No!
We got lucky.
 
https://t.co/VMyMV1WOwd

6. Build a process

Most of us are scared of losing what we have, because we do not know how to get it again.

Build a process, where you can get anything again.
Tasks you do repeatedly (tossing the coin), and then trust the process.

I recall sending a note to a founder wishing them well after a fund raise.
I did not know of the founder. Simply admired the product from a distance.

They asked if I was keen to invest.
I said yes.
I am sitting on a 8X on that investment in 3 years!

5. Wish people 

On their birthdays, anniversaries, congratulate them on their accomplishments.

Be thoughtful. 
Be nice.
Be authentic.

4. Be nice to people

People do not remember what you did to them. 
They remember how you made them feel.

Life is too short to be rude, angry, hurt or  conniving.
Being nice to others is the single biggest determinant of luck coming your way!

Who knows which one of them will click and how?

My sister, a professor, loves to dance. Almost 2 years back decided to start an IG channel for it.
Today, she teaches Zoology to undergrads.
And dance to students all across the world.

She chose teaching as a luck engine!

3. Pursue multiple side gigs

We have grown up in a culture of devotional commitment.
One career. One field. One industry. 

We have just one life.
Why live it with just one identity?

Pursue multiple interests.
With no pressure of making money from them.
Purely for the joy of it

Today, the Internet allows us to be in direct connect with the most successful and smartest men and women in the world.

And they rarely come across thoughtful engagement.

Become that person, and you increase your chances to get lucky.

2.  Engage with people online

You like somebody's work, send them an appreciation note.
You wish to know about something that was shared, ask questions.
You have your own experience to add, do not hesitate.

Half of my current team has been hired through cold emails.
I have got investors on board through cold emails.
Search for "cold emails" on twitter and you will come across mega success stories.

Here is a thread that might help
https://t.co/6cTiXJeX4e

1. Send cold emails

You have at best a 10% chance of receiving a reply to a cold email.
However, if you send one every day to different people, it is almost certain you will receive a reply from someone!

And that might be all you need.

One of the most powerful ways to get lucky, is to "toss the coin" as many times as you can.
In other words, set a process that sets you up for success.

Here are 10 such processes that you could use.

Let's say you WANT atleast 1 heads.
That 1 heads will change your life!

If you toss the coin once, there is a 50% chance you get lucky.
However, if you tossed the coin 10 times, the probability is ~100%

Sorry what?
What changed?

Just one thing.
You tossed the coin 10 times!

If you toss a coin, the chances that it will land on heads/tails is 50%.

Let's call that luck.
We do not control it.
We can only observe it.

So it may seem that we can't do anything to do to influence it.
That's partly true.

How to get lucky in life.

So do not wish for your haters to go away. Do not give them the joy of a special position in your world and your thoughts. 

Instead, pray for their well being. 
Realize that for every such hater, there is an admirer as well.
Be aware of them. Do not chase them.

Peace isn't being perpetually happy.
It is being divorced from wanting to be perpetually happy.
To embrace both positivity and negativity as a reality, without any emotional attachment or aversion, is ironically the only way to gather peace.

But when you read both the hate and life-changing, don't seek one side, wishing the other side away. 
Instead, realize that both sides are a reality.

I told my team, any day you feel terrible about yourself and question how your work impacts anyone, go to this folder. 

Not to seek validation. 
But to define positivity.

I wouldn't reproduce them, because that would be too cocky. 

Visualize this... 
People thanking us.
Sharing how our content pulled them out of their darkest moments.
Helped them connect with their lost relationships, including the one they had with themselves.

Instead, do not seek positivity either.

Remember, our Google drive has a folder called life-changing?

It contains precious emails and messages from people who thank us for the work we do. How we have helped them change their life.

We try and run away from negativity, towards positivity, but it is futile.

Because positivity is the awareness of negativity, the acceptance of negativity, the acknowledgement of it.

As long as we are chasing positivity, we cannot ignore negativity. 

When we say we do not want negativity in our life, we are admitting to understanding the definition of negativity. 
And its impact on us.

The next time you find yourself in the middle of a toxic remark, a hate situation, a non-physical "fight", see if deploying empathy towards the person helps you. 

There is a strong chance it will. 

If it doesn't, here is the 4th bonus approach.

And I kid you not, I found myself feeling so terribly sorry for this person. 

Because this person might not have anyone to speak to. No one to share what they are going through. 
So much so that they decided to send such an anger filled note to some random dude on the internet.

I was imaging the life of this individual. 

Did they sleep at all? Did they just wake up? Did they see something that triggered this reaction? It can't be just me. 

This person must have a really hard life.
They must be really angry.
Not at me.
Not at themselves.
At life!

When I received this particular email, I found myself laughing, because I found it funny. 
And then I looked at the timestamp.

Suddenly, I was overcome with massive sadness. https://t.co/I33VcX5P6f

What?
Empathize with the haters? 
The ones spewing venom?

Yes.
I am arguing that you need to try and empathize with them.

When one reads these, there are 3 possible reactions:
1. Go into a dark mode and take 2-3 days to recover from it, questioning everything about your existence
2. Try and ignore the haters, because that's what we are told (but it rarely works)
3. Empathize with the haters

Every Friday I write a thread on personal growth, failures, startups, organization building and more.

You can follow me on @warikoo to get them on your feed.
Congratulating an entrepreneur on raising money is like congratulating a chef on buying vegetables.

Let us start applauding entrepreneurs for running successful business. 
Not for raising money!

The bootstrapped experience is fascinating though.

In a world where funding is lauded, covered in the press, shown on national TV and heralded as a mark of success, I would love for people to realize that it isn't the only way.

And that for me, is the fulfilling part of running a startup.
 
The joy of building products, getting feedback from users, improvising, making money, building a team, sharing wealth with all - all of this gives me a high!

The name of the startup? 
Not important!

The goal of the startup?
Not important!

Will it become big/successful?
Not important!

What is important is that students benefit from it, I am wedded to it and I have a kick-ass team @waricrew that delivers on the process clinically.

I draw inspiration everyday from @vishen building @mindvalley, @eriktorenberg building @beondeck, @garyvee building his brand, @anafabrega11 evangelizing @synthesischool and so many more wonderful people.

The year, in terms of student enrollments

110K: Time Management
40K: Startup
20K: Public Speaking

10 yrs of this and we might touch 10Mn students! https://t.co/ZRi0Zk3gcD
All of this while owning 100% of the company, working with super smart/fun people, creating wealth for all, doing it on your own pace, while meaningfully helping people.

5c. Keep shipping

Every 6 months, we launch a new course.

"Complete Guide to starting up"
"Take charge of your time"
"How to YouTube"

Each is designed to become a $2Mn/yr course, with minimal time investment.

10 such courses over time and we will easily be a $50-100Mn company

5b. Keep upgrading

Every course is upgraded every 3 months. 
Every student has lifetime free access to these upgrades.
If they benefit, we will benefit.

5a. Build properties

Not "Time Management"
"Take charge of your time"

Not "startup course"
"Complete guide to starting up"

Not "Ankur Warikoo"
"Brand warikoo"

Not "Do epic shit - a book"
"DO EPIC SHIT - a brand"

Help people associate with an identity.

5. Be super patient

Education is a hard category to crack.
So I am in no hurry. 

I have no investor to please.
I have no image to live up to.
I have no goals or targets.

I am simply committed to a process...

People seek a refund for the weirdest of reasons. Some even after a year!
But we happily issue the refund.

https://t.co/q6pfv6CO9P

Despite this, our refund is only 4.4%
It is my job to keep it below 5% always!

4. Stay true to the purpose

The purpose of these courses is very clear. Help students. 

So if it doesn't help, you cannot be making money off it. 

We offer an unconditional 100% refund policy.

a) 100% self paced, with videos, notes, exercises and a community

b) Option a + live QnA class every month

65% go for Option b, which is 80% more expensive. 
I invest one-time a significant amount of energy for option A. And then get massive leverage for my time through op B.

3. Build assets

Assets make money for you, while you sleep!
Last 2 years has been a massive surge towards CBCs (Cohort Based Courses), which is a massive drain on the instructor's time. 
I did not want to go down that route. 

I introduced 2 options for every course...

2c. Lean Operations

The entire operations is managed between me and 1 FTE.
And technology for everything! 

This allows for me to run this at low cost, and distribute profits back to the team (this year ~100K will be distributed within the team, from the profits)

2b. Advertising RoI of >1.8

For every $ I spend on Facebook and Google, I need to make ~$2. This is sacrosanct. 

We keep spending, till we are above this. We scale back, when this number moves down.

We started with a daily ad spend of $75. 
Today, we spend $3,000+ every day!

2a. No code operations

My monthly software bill is $3,300, which is HUGE as a SaaS customer, but will not buy even 1 half decent engineer in India today. 

I have the world's best engineers from @razorpay @learnworlds @convertkit @zoom @freshworksinc @adobe working for me!

2. Make money from Day 1

After running funded ventures for 10 years, I did not want to raise money. 
And I did not have my own money :)

This meant, designing the business to make money from day 1.

Which inturn meant...

...they see years of content that they hopefully like and appreciate.

My landing page conversion is 7%.
For those who come to the page, don't buy, check my content and then come again, the conversion is 36%!

This means that none of my content ever speaks about my courses. 
It only tries to help the audience, in whatever manner I can.

My content reaches 13Mn every month.
My advertising reached 25Mn every month.

So when people see my ads, ask "who is this guy" and then look me up...

1. Content as a trust engine

I have been writing a blog everyday since 2005.
I have been creating content on LinkedIn since 2013.
I have been on YT/IG since 2017.

When you create content, you can either use it a sales engine or a trust engine.

I chose to use it for trust.

Last week, that education company hit 150,000+ paid students. 

In Jan 2022, the company did $200,000 (Rs. 1.42Cr) of sales, thus making it a $2.5Mn run-rate company.

Here is the story of how it happened... https://t.co/qwtTELVkQS

In May 2011, I registered a company. 

I just had started the Groupon India business, so I didn't intend to use the company for a while. 

But I knew I would use it someday.

That someday happened in Jan 2021, 10 years later!

It was an education company.

Bootstrapping an education startup to 150,000+ paid students and $2.5Mn of revenue, in 12 months.

Every Friday I write a thread on personal growth, failures, startups, organization building and more.

You can follow me on @warikoo to get them on your feed.

"Parents are first humans. By treating them as gods, we treat them unfairly. Each time they fail, we question them. When we should instead understand them."

"Kids are their parent's replica. They can either give them their values. Or make them live their life. It's a choice."

Both of these can change.

Kids:
Start by understanding WHY parents behave the way they do.
Appreciate where they come from.

Parents:
Recognize that there are multiple ways to get to the same outcome. Trust your kids to experiment, fail and figure their own way.

It baffles me how little people are taught about parenting and how critical and sensitive a role it plays in shaping the entire world. 

It baffles me how many of us grow up loving our parents but eventually resenting them as we discover how they influenced us adversely.

This thread is meant to make you aware how your parents, for no fault of theirs, could impact you as an individual. 

And for parents to be aware of how their actions drive an entire life.

So most of how they parented us, was driven by what worked for them.

While those ways may not work anymore, do remember that they most certainly want the same things for your life that you want for yours. 

It is the worldview that differs. Not the outcome.

This thread can easily be treated as one against parents.
It is not.

Our parents had an immensely hard, demanding life.
Survival was key.

They lived a life trying to just make ends meet.
Life didn't have options.

11. Not making us accountable

When we fail, we are either blamed, or we are absolved of it because it was someone else's fault.

When we fall as a toddler, it is the floor that is beaten up.

So we rarely grow up to take responsibility for our actions.

10. Imposing relationships

We are often ordered to maintain relationships, simply because we were born into them. 
Even if those relationships do not work for us.

Thus a lot of us grow up with a complicated relationship with our own selves.
"Is there something wrong with me?"

9. Unreasonable expectations

Because our parents had a difficult different life, they often wish to experience life through their kids.

Thus imposing expectations that we did not get to chose for ourselves.

What is success for us, is often defined without our permission.

8. No discussion about Money

Most of us grow up with zero understanding of income, expenses, taxes, investments.

And thus have a complicated relationship with money that we understand much later.
By which time it is often late.

7. Lack of trust

In a trust-deficient society, parents tend to start with mistrust than trust. 

"Daal mein kuch kaala hai" (there is something wrong) is the operative we are raised on.

We are rarely trusted.
So we grow up to rarely trust.

6.  Dismissing Mental Health

Mental health wasn't a topic for our parents, growing up.
People were sent to mental hospitals.

So it is easy for them to dismiss mental health as either a fad ("you can come out of it if you want to") or a illness to be ashamed of.

4. Looking at the world only through their own experiences

Our parents had a very different and difficult life.
Which, for no fault of theirs, has biased them.

The world has changed though.
Their biases haven't.

3. Focusing on society

Society is somehow more important than us. 
What we do in life, who we marry, how we dress, where we work.

Decisions that should be ours, become decisions driven by others. 
Faceless people, who opinions are apparently more important than our feelings.

2. Killing curiosity

As kids all that we did was ask questions. 
Before we were told not to.

Asking means we do not understand. 
Asking means we are dumb. 
Asking means we admit to being dumb.
So don't ask.

We stop asking.
We memorize answers.
Instead of loving questions.

1. Comparison

We are often compared to others, in the hope that it elevates our game. 

However, the constant comparison makes us feel that nothing we do will be good enough. 
Because there will always be someone to compare ourselves with!

11 ways where Indian parents go wrong.

Every Friday I write a thread on personal growth, failures, startups, organization building and more.

You can follow me on @warikoo to get them on your feed.

You do not become cool laughing at others.
You become cool by being yourself!
Those in a corporate job, laughing at those in a startup job, are laughing at the same people they wish they could have become.
Those in a startup job, laughing at those in a corporate job, are laughing at the same people that they themselves will soon become.

What a corporate job or a startup job does to you, is a function of who you are at that point of time in life.

There is no right or wrong.
You define that.
For yourself.

I can see how an MBA, a consulting job, founder of a small bootstrapped venture, an executive role in a multi-billion dollar tech startup, a founder in a VC backed startup - have all contributed to get me to this point.

After 5 years as a founder of a VC-backed venture, I am back to starting up, bootstrapping yet again. 

Playing a very different game from what I have played before.

So after 4 years, I started up again, this time as VC backed. Leaving the financial stability, prestige, power that came with the executive role.

The journey wasn't any easier, but it was enriching. I could see how my 4 years of corporate role had shaped me as a leader.

After 2 years, I went back to an executive role, this time at a really large MNC.

I learnt the power of processes, planning, methodical execution.
And also how large companies can crush your soul, if you are not that person.
I was not that person.

I started my career in a consulting firm, where everything was about process and teams.
Did that for 3 years, before starting a bootstrapped venture. 

The concept of "structure" that I learnt at consulting, helped me tremendously as a founder.

A debate on Corporate vs Startup jobs isn't about them.
It is about you.

Where do you see yourself fitting in more?
Where do you see yourself growing more?
Learning more?
Failing better?

A startup job will come with transparent communication.
You'll know how the company is doing, how you are doing, more often than you would wish to know.

If transparency appeals to you, the choice works for you.
If radical candor is hard to digest, the choice works against you.

A corporate job will train you adequately for your role. 
It will offer tools, skills, mentoring and feedback, at every step.

If you prefer structured learning, the choice works for you.
If you prefer learning via trial and error on the job, the choice works against you.

A startup job will offer you professional growth that is thrilling.
You will be given a mandate far bigger, far earlier than expected.

If you prefer given a role and then growing into it, the choice works for you.
If you prefer growing into a role, the choice works against you.

A corporate job will discuss, debate before taking decisions.
The damage of a decision gone bad is far greater. 

If you love taking decisions by analysis and conversation, the choice works for you.
If you love taking decisions by your gut, the choice works against you.

A startup job nurtures you as a generalist.
You handle multiple roles at the same time, while learning about them on the job.

If you wish to build a generalist profile, the choice works for you.
If you wish to specialize, the choice may not work for you.

A corporate job more often than not comes with brand recognition.
You do not have to explain where you work.

If the brand adds to your credentials, the choices works for you.
If you are doing it for social validation, the choice works against you.

A startup job offer a very small probability of a very big life-changing financial outcome.

If taking risks comes naturally to you, the choice may work for you.
If taking risks isn't you, the choice may work against you.

A corporate job requires you to communicate effectively, in order to convince people to deploy resources.

If you believe persuasion is just as important as capability, the choice works for you.
If you believe your work should speak for itself, the choice works against you.

A startup job tends to fail fast.
Feedback loops are short and you get to see the impact of your work quickly.

If you tend to reflect on all of your failures, the choice works for you.
If you tend to move on quickly from your failures, the choice works against you.

A corporate job shows the power of teams.
How the microcosm of your work adds up to a collective outcome.

If you love to see huge indirect outcome of your work, the choice works for you.
If you love to see micro direct outcome of your work, the choice works against you.

A startup job's flat hierarchy gives you access to the leadership.
You witness them up-close.

If the comprehension gap between them and you isn't wide, then the choice works for you.
If its wide and you fail to understand most of what they do, then the choice works against you.

A corporate job shows you the power of process and systems.
Of planning in advance towards an outcome far out.

If you wish to aim and shoot, then the choice works for you.
If you to shoot and then check if you hit the aim, then the choice works against you.

A startup job will throw you into an ocean of ambiguity.
Where you will have to navigate most of the journey yourself.

If ambiguity doesn't intimidate you, then the choice works for you.
If ambiguity weakens you, then the choice works against you.

A corporate job is likely to give you financial stability.
The probability of the next paycheck is higher.

If money is a necessity, then the choice works for you.
If salary becomes an addiction, then the choice works against you.

Corporate vs Startup jobs

Every Friday I write a thread on personal growth, failures, startups, organization building and more.

You can follow me on @warikoo to get them on your feed.
What are some life hacks that work for you? Reply with them here.

If the climb is tough, but needs to be done, then ignore the mountain in front of you.

Take the smallest possible step forward to get you started.

Hacks are great ways to accomplish critical tasks by making them look simple.

They get us started. 
And starting is a great thing!

25. Take breaks

Our mind gets distracted.
Give it some space.

Follow the pomodoro technique.
25 mins of work
5 mins break
Repeat
After 2-4 of such Pomodoros, take a longer 20 min break.

24. Teach people

When you teach something, your own understanding of what you are teaching gets better.

23. Follow positive thoughts

Unfollow those who make you laugh at other people's expense, those who make you feel jealous, though you make you feel ugly or incapable, those who spread hatred and anger.

You are the 5 ideas you spend most time with.

22. Smile at the mirror

Say good morning to yourself
Good night
I love you
You are enough

Or say nothing. 
Look at yourself in the eye.
And just smile :)

21. Help strangers

When out, if you see somebody who needs help, help them.

Helping those you do not know, makes you feel good about yourself.
You know you have nothing to gain from it.

20. Every night, look at the stars for 2 mins

Just you, and the sky. 
No clicking pictures.
No one else.
No music.
Nothing.

Just look at the stars. 
Imagine how big the world is.
How there is space for everything and everyone.
Including you!

19. Write angry letters. But don't send them.

Whenever angry, write down all that you are feeling. Record your voice, if writing is hard. Give your emotions an outlet.

And then don't destroy them.

18. Keep a gratitude jar

Everyday, before going to bed, write down something that you are grateful for.
Anything at all.

Place it in the jar.

In moments of weakness, go through the notes.

17. Don't buy water

Carry a bottle with you, wherever you go.

Ask for regular water at restaurants (that is what they are cooking your food in, as well)

16. Buy Term Life Insurance when you are young

It will be way cheaper
You will get covered for much longer

15. Use credit cards

They offer 30-45 days free credit
They give you rewards points
They help you with your credit rating

However, always, ALWAYS pay the bill in full.

14. Lower the tenure, not the EMI

If your interest rate reduces, do not lower the EMI. Lower the tenure of the loan.

If you find a cheaper interest rate, opt for it.

Do whatever you can, to save on interest paid!

13. The 30-day rule

When you desire a big purchase, do not buy it right away.
Give yourself 30 days and ask yourself if you still it just as much as you did earlier.

If you do, go for it.
Chances are you won't.

12. Do not put pressure on your hobby to make money

Pursue it through a side gig. 
Let it give you joy.
Get really good at it.
Take your time.

The day your side income replaces your main income, quit your job!

11. If you have a loan, increase your EMI by 5% every year and pay 1 extra EMI every year

Your 25 year loan will now be paid in 13 years!

10. Have a separate bank account for investments

The day you get your monthly salary, auto-transfer atleast 20% of that to the investment bank account.

You have to manage with the rest. Go figure!

9. Don't watch news

News is meant to scintillate you, in the guise of information.

News will convince you the world is falling apart, while making you feel guilty for not doing anything about it.

8. Create a self-whatsapp group

Create a WA group with you and your best friend. 
Delete the best friend. Now the group has only you.
Pin the group to the top.

Use this group for sharing thoughts, capturing images, voice notes to yourself, whatever you want it to be!

7. Put timer limits for apps where you waste time

Protect the timer limits by a passcode.
Let your family/friends decide the passcode and not share it with you.

When time is up, it is up!

6. Always ask for "by when do you need this?"

Whenever given a task, even if an order, always check for the deadline.

Very often we have a different definition of urgency in our minds.

5. Address people by their names

When drafting a message or email, or replying to one, when saying hello or replying to their hello, say out people's names.

You will never forget it then.
And they will feel loved!

4. Predict your future (and then laugh about it)

Every birthday, write down 2-3 predictions for yourself, for the next year. 

And then next birthday, go through them.

Over 3-5 years you will be amazed at how inaccurate your predictions were!

3. Do not try to remember anything! 

Write everything down. 
Put things on a calendar.
Create a to-do list.
Use a notes app.

We over-estimate our ability to remember things!

2. Send emails to your future self.

It could be a task, a prediction, a thought. Compose the email and schedule send it for sometime later. 

It is joyful when we have forgotten about something and then hear from our own selves.

1. When speaking to others, try and notice the color of their eye balls. 

This will maintain eye contact without you feeling awkward.
While making them feel heard.

25 immensely powerful life hacks.

Reading books can change lives. 

Which is why, I wanted to write a book that have the same impact on others that reading comic books had on me.

"make one fall in love with books"

https://t.co/xSYV4XunFa

It blows my mind that in 200-300 rupees, I get to read about the entire life, mistakes, adventures, experiences and lessons of an individual. 

And I am so glad that I have the same child-like enthusiasm approaching any new book, even today.

In 11th grade, I became friends with Kunal, who had ALL the series of Archies, Asterix and Tintin.
I devoured them in less than 2 months! 

We both talked endlessly about Aliens. 
One day he mentioned, "Have you read Chariots of the Gods?"

And that was it...

As our financial condition improved, I now could buy a comic, during the train journey we undertook during summer holidays.

Thus started my adventure with Chacha Chaudhary, Pinki, Billu, Nagraaj, Super Commando Dhruv.

Growing up, I never read books.

It was in the 5th standard, during a visit to my mom's relatives, that they gave me 17 Enid Blyton books.

For the next 2 years, I read and re-read them.
They were my best friends.

17. Courage to be disliked
40 years

Through this book I was able to explain so many of my relationships that I had struggled with, including the one I had with my own self. 
One of the most powerful books I have read.

https://t.co/UQjJQFfPVw
